An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a swelling of the aorta, the main blood vessel that leads away from the heart.
Large AAAs can be very serious and can cause massive internal bleeding if they burst.
Symptoms of an AAA may include a pulsating feeling in the abdomen, persistent back pain, and persistent abdominal pain.
Risk factors for an AAA include increasing age, being male, smoking, having high blood pressure and cholesterol levels, and having a family history of AAAs.
Acne is a common skin condition that causes spots, oily skin, and sometimes pain or heat in the affected areas.
There are six main types of spots caused by acne, including blackheads, whiteheads, papules, pustules, nodules, and cysts.

Self-help techniques for managing acne include washing affected areas no more than twice a day, using mild soap or cleanser, avoiding squeezing or picking at spots, and avoiding excessive makeup or cosmetics.

Treatment options for acne include over-the-counter topical treatments, prescription medications like retinoids and antibiotics, hormonal therapies, and in severe cases, isotretinoin or cosmetic procedures for scarring.
Acute cholecystitis is swelling (inflammation) of the gallbladder and is a potentially serious condition that usually needs to be treated in hospital.
The main symptom of acute cholecystitis is a sudden sharp pain in the upper right side of the abdomen that spreads towards the right shoulder.
Additional symptoms may include a high temperature (fever), nausea and vomiting, sweating, loss of appetite, yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice), and a bulge in the abdomen.

Acute cholecystitis can be caused by calculous cholecystitis, which occurs when the cystic duct is blocked by a gallstone or biliary sludge, or acalculous cholecystitis, which usually develops as a complication of a serious illness, infection, or injury.
Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia is a type of cancer that affects the white blood cells and progresses rapidly, requiring immediate treatment.
Symptoms of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia include pale skin, tiredness, repeated infections, unusual bleeding, high temperature, night sweats, bone and joint pain, and neurological symptoms.
The cause of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia is a DNA mutation in the stem cells, leading to the overproduction of white blood cells and a decrease in healthy red blood cells and platelets.
Treatment for acute lymphoblastic leukaemia involves chemotherapy, steroid therapy, imatinib for specific cases, and possibly bone marrow or stem cell transplantation.
Leukaemia is a cancer of the white blood cells that affects the production of normal blood cells in the bone marrow.
Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) is a type of leukaemia that primarily affects children aged 1 to 4 years old.
Symptoms of ALL may include tiredness, bruising, bleeding, infections, aches and pains, and swollen lymph glands.
Treatment for ALL typically involves chemotherapy given in different phases, including induction, consolidation, maintenance, and sometimes bone marrow transplantation or radiotherapy.
Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) is a type of cancer that affects the white blood cells and can cause symptoms such as fatigue, bruising, infections, bone pain, swollen glands, and fever.
The exact cause of ALL is unknown, but certain genetic conditions, such as Down's syndrome or Li-Fraumeni syndrome, can increase the risk of developing the condition.
Diagnosis of ALL involves blood tests, bone marrow tests, lumbar puncture, and chest X-rays to check for leukaemia cells and determine the extent of the disease.
Treatment for ALL typically involves chemotherapy, including anti-cancer drugs and steroids, given in different phases to eliminate the leukaemia cells and prevent relapse.
Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a rapidly progressing and aggressive cancer of the myeloid cells in the bone marrow.
Symptoms of AML include pale skin, tiredness, breathlessness, frequent infections, and unusual bleeding.
AML is caused by a DNA mutation in the stem cells of the bone marrow, leading to the overproduction of immature white blood cells.
Treatment for AML usually involves intensive chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and possibly a bone marrow or stem cell transplant.
Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a type of blood cancer that affects children of any age.
AML is characterized by an overproduction of immature myeloid white blood cells.
The FAB classification system categorizes AML into different sub-types based on the type and stage of development of the leukaemic cells.
Treatment for AML usually involves chemotherapy, including induction and post-remission phases, and may also include bone marrow transplant and central nervous system treatment.
Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a type of cancer that affects the white blood cells and can cause symptoms such as fatigue, bruising or bleeding, infections, bone pain, swollen glands, and fever.
The exact cause of AML is unknown, but certain genetic conditions and non-cancerous conditions of the bone marrow may increase the risk of developing this type of leukaemia.
If you experience symptoms of AML, it is important to see a doctor for a proper diagnosis, as these symptoms can also be caused by other conditions.

Treatment for AML usually involves chemotherapy, which aims to destroy the leukaemia cells and achieve remission. Additional treatments such as bone marrow transplant or central nervous system therapy may be necessary in some cases.
Acute pancreatitis is a serious condition where the pancreas becomes inflamed over a short period of time.
The main symptom of acute pancreatitis is a severe, dull pain around the top of your stomach that develops suddenly.
Most cases of acute pancreatitis are closely linked to gallstones or to alcohol consumption.
Treatment for acute pancreatitis focuses on supporting the functions of the body until the inflammation has passed.
Addison's disease is a rare disorder of the adrenal glands that occurs when the adrenal gland is damaged and not enough cortisol and aldosterone are produced.
Early symptoms of Addison's disease include fatigue, muscle weakness, low mood, loss of appetite, increased thirst, and unintentional weight loss.
Addison's disease is usually caused by a problem with the immune system, which attacks the outer layer of the adrenal gland, disrupting hormone production.
Treatment for Addison's disease involves taking medication to replace the missing hormones and managing bouts of fatigue.
Alcohol-related liver disease (ARLD) is caused by drinking too much alcohol and can lead to liver damage.
Symptoms of ARLD can include abdominal pain, loss of appetite, fatigue, yellowing of the skin and eyes, swelling in the legs and abdomen, confusion, and vomiting blood.
ARLD has three main stages: alcoholic fatty liver disease, alcoholic hepatitis, and cirrhosis.
Treatment for ARLD involves stopping drinking alcohol, and in severe cases, a liver transplant may be necessary.
Allergic rhinitis is inflammation of the inside of the nose caused by allergens such as pollen, dust, mold, or animal skin.
Symptoms of allergic rhinitis include sneezing, itchiness, and a blocked or runny nose, usually triggered by contact with allergens.
Mild cases of allergic rhinitis can be treated with over-the-counter medications, nasal saline solution, and avoiding triggers.
Complications of allergic rhinitis may include nasal polyps, sinusitis, and blockage of the middle ear, which can be treated with medication or surgery.
An allergy is a reaction the body has to a particular food or substance.
Allergies are very common, affecting more than 1 in 4 people in the UK at some point in their lives.
Common allergens include grass and tree pollen, dust mites, animal dander, food, insect bites and stings, medication, latex, mould, and household chemicals.
Symptoms of an allergic reaction can include sneezing, runny or blocked nose, itchy and watery eyes, wheezing and coughing, a red and itchy rash, and worsening of asthma or eczema symptoms.
Alzheimer's disease is the most common type of dementia, affecting an estimated 850,000 people in the UK.

The exact cause of Alzheimer's disease is unknown, but increasing age, family history, previous severe head injuries, and lifestyle factors associated with cardiovascular disease can increase the risk.

The symptoms of Alzheimer's disease develop gradually and become more severe over several years, starting with minor memory problems and progressing to confusion, disorientation, difficulty planning, problems with speech and language, and personality changes.

There is currently no cure for Alzheimer's disease, but medication can help relieve some symptoms and slow down the progression of the condition. Other supportive measures and treatments, such as occupational therapy and psychological therapies, are also available to help people with Alzheimer's live as independently as possible.
Anal cancer is a rare type of cancer that affects the very end of the large bowel.
Symptoms of anal cancer can include bleeding from the bottom, itching and pain around the anus, small lumps around the anus, a discharge of mucus from the anus, and loss of bowel control.
Diagnosing anal cancer may involve examinations such as a rectal examination and tests such as sigmoidoscopy and biopsy.
Treatment for anal cancer may involve chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy and radiotherapy, or surgery to remove the tumor or a larger section of the bowel.
Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can develop rapidly.
Signs of anaphylaxis include itchy skin or a raised, red skin rash, swollen eyes, lips, hands and feet, feeling lightheaded or faint, and swelling of the mouth, throat or tongue.
Anaphylaxis can be triggered by insect stings, peanuts and tree nuts, other types of foods, and certain medicines.
Treatment for anaphylaxis involves using an adrenaline injector, calling 999 for an ambulance, and receiving further treatment in the hospital.
Angina is chest pain caused by restricted blood supply to the heart due to narrowing or blockages in the blood vessels around the heart.
Symptoms of angina include chest pain that can feel like a dull ache or tightness in the chest, and may spread to the arms, neck, jaw, or back. It is often triggered by physical exertion.
Angina can be diagnosed through assessments and tests such as electrocardiogram (ECG), exercise tolerance test (ETT), myocardial perfusion scan (MPS), and coronary angiography.

Treatment for angina includes medications such as nitrates, beta blockers, and calcium channel blockers to prevent and treat angina attacks, as well as reducing the risk of heart attack or stroke. In some cases, surgery such as coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) or percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) may be recommended.
Angioedema is the swelling of the deeper layers of the skin, caused by a build-up of fluid.
The symptoms of angioedema can affect any part of the body, but swelling usually affects the eyes, lips, genitals, hands, and feet.
Angioedema can be caused by allergic reactions, idiopathic (unknown cause), drug side effects, or hereditary factors.
Treatment for angioedema may involve antihistamines, corticosteroids, alternative medications, or preventative measures for hereditary cases.

The main symptoms of ankylosing spondylitis are back pain and stiffness that improve with exercise and are not relieved by rest, pain and swelling in other joints such as the hips and knees, and fatigue.

Ankylosing spondylitis can cause complications such as reduced flexibility in the spine, joint damage, iritis (inflammation of the eye), osteoporosis and spinal fractures, cardiovascular disease, cauda equina syndrome, amyloidosis, and difficulties with employment.
Ankylosing spondylitis is usually diagnosed through physical assessments, blood tests to check for inflammation, and imaging tests such as X-rays, MRI scans, and ultrasound scans.

Treatment for ankylosing spondylitis may include exercise and physiotherapy to improve posture and flexibility, painkillers such as NSAIDs and paracetamol, anti-TNF medication to reduce inflammation, corticosteroids for joint inflammation, DMARDs for joint pain and inflammation in areas other than the spine, and surgery in severe cases.
Anorexia nervosa is a serious, potentially life-threatening, mental health condition characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight and a strict control over food intake.
Symptoms of anorexia include a fear of being fat or gaining weight, problems with self-esteem and body image, restricting food intake, and maintaining an unhealthy body weight.
Physical symptoms of anorexia can include the growth of fine downy hair on the body, irregular heartbeat, abdominal pain, bloating, fatigue, low blood pressure, and feeling cold.
Treatment for anorexia typically involves a combination of talking therapy and supervised weight gain, and it is important to start treatment as early as possible to reduce the risk of complications.
Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD) is a long-term condition that causes individuals to feel anxious about a wide range of issues.
Symptoms of GAD include restlessness, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle aches and tension, and difficulty falling or staying asleep.
The exact cause of GAD is not fully understood, but factors such as overactivity in certain areas of the brain, imbalances in brain chemicals, and genetic predisposition may play a role.
Treatment options for GAD include talking therapies like cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) and medication such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).
Anxiety is a feeling of unease, like worry or fear, that can affect a child's behavior and thoughts on a daily basis.

Signs of anxiety in children may include difficulty concentrating, sleep disturbances, changes in appetite, irritability, constant worrying, physical symptoms such as stomachaches, and withdrawal from activities.
Common types of anxiety in children and teenagers include specific phobias, generalized anxiety disorder, separation anxiety, and school-based anxiety.
Long-term anxiety can severely interfere with a child's personal development, family life, and schooling, and may lead to other mental health issues such as depression and substance misuse.
Appendicitis is a painful swelling of the appendix, a small pouch connected to the large intestine.
Symptoms of appendicitis include pain in the middle of the abdomen that travels to the lower right-hand side, nausea, loss of appetite, and diarrhea.
Appendicitis is usually treated by surgically removing the appendix through either keyhole surgery or open surgery.
Complications of appendicitis include peritonitis, a potentially life-threatening infection of the abdomen, and abscesses, which may require drainage.
Arterial thrombosis is a blood clot that develops in an artery and can obstruct or stop the flow of blood to major organs.
Symptoms of arterial thrombosis depend on where the blood clot has formed and can include angina, heart attack, stroke, and peripheral vascular disease.
The main cause of arterial thrombosis is atherosclerosis, which is the buildup of fatty deposits on the walls of the arteries.
Treatment for arterial thrombosis can involve medication to dissolve clots or surgery to unblock or reroute blood flow.
Arthritis is a common condition that causes pain and inflammation in a joint.
The two most common types of arthritis are osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
Osteoarthritis affects the smooth cartilage lining of the joint, leading to pain and stiffness.
Rheumatoid arthritis occurs when the body's immune system targets affected joints, causing pain and swelling.
Asbestosis is a chronic lung condition caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos.
Symptoms of asbestosis include shortness of breath, persistent cough, wheezing, fatigue, chest pain, and clubbed fingertips.
There is no cure for asbestosis, but treatments such as oxygen therapy can improve quality of life.
Asbestosis can increase the risk of developing other serious conditions such as pleural disease, mesothelioma, and lung cancer.
Asthma is a common long-term condition that can cause coughing, wheezing, chest tightness and breathlessness.
Asthma can be controlled well in most people most of the time, although some people may have more persistent problems.
Severe asthma attacks may require hospital treatment and can be life threatening, although this is unusual.
Treatment for asthma involves the use of reliever inhalers to relieve symptoms and preventer inhalers to reduce inflammation and prevent future symptoms and attacks.
Atopic eczema, also known as atopic dermatitis, is the most common form of eczema that mainly affects children but can also affect adults.

The symptoms of atopic eczema include itchy, red, dry, and cracked skin, with common areas of the body affected being the backs or fronts of the knees, outside or inside of the elbows, around the neck, hands, cheeks, and scalp.
The exact cause of atopic eczema is unknown, but it often occurs in people who have allergies and can run in families or develop alongside other conditions such as asthma and hay fever.

Treatment for atopic eczema includes using emollients (moisturizers) to keep the skin hydrated, topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation during flare-ups, antihistamines to relieve itching, and in some cases, bandages or wet wraps to protect and heal the skin.
Atrial fibrillation is a condition that causes an irregular heart rate.
A normal heart rate, when resting, should be between 60 and 100 beats a minute. In atrial fibrillation, it may be over 140 beats a minute.
Atrial fibrillation is defined as paroxysmal, persistent, longstanding persistent, or permanent, depending on how it affects the individual.
Symptoms of atrial fibrillation may include dizziness, feeling faint, shortness of breath, fast and irregular heartbeat (palpitations), and feeling very tired.
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a group of behavioural symptoms that include difficulty concentrating and paying attention, hyperactivity, and impulsiveness.

Symptoms of ADHD in children and teenagers include inattentiveness (short attention span, easily distracted, forgetfulness), hyperactivity and impulsiveness (inability to sit still, fidgeting, excessive talking), and little or no sense of danger.
Symptoms of ADHD in adults include easily getting distracted, difficulty listening and following instructions, trouble organizing tasks, restlessness, forgetfulness, and difficulty handling stress.

ADHD can be caused by a combination of factors, including genetics and differences in brain function and structure. Certain groups, such as those born prematurely or with brain damage, may be at higher risk.
Autism spectrum disorder (ASD), also known as autism, is a condition that affects the way a person thinks, feels, and experiences the world.
Autism is highly variable and is experienced differently by each individual. It can affect social interactions, communication, and behavior.
Many autistic individuals prefer to use the term "autistic" to describe themselves, as they see autism as part of their identity.
Autism can be diagnosed in childhood or later in life, and early intervention and support can be beneficial for autistic children.
Bacterial vaginosis is an imbalance of the usual bacteria found in the vagina and is not a sexually transmitted infection.
Symptoms of bacterial vaginosis may include a change in the normal discharge from the vagina, such as white or grey discharge with a strong fishy smell.

To determine if you have bacterial vaginosis, you can check if certain toiletries are triggering it, consider over-the-counter treatments, or contact your GP or local sexual health service for an appointment.
Bacterial vaginosis is treated with antibiotics, either in the form of tablets or creams/gels, and partners do not usually need treatment.
Benign prostate enlargement (BPE), also known as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), is a condition that affects older men and anyone with a prostate.
The main symptoms of benign prostate enlargement include difficulty starting urination, frequent need to urinate, and difficulty fully emptying the bladder.
The exact cause of benign prostate enlargement is unknown, but it is believed to be linked to hormonal changes that occur as a man gets older.
Treatment for benign prostate enlargement can include lifestyle changes, medication, and surgery, depending on the severity of symptoms.
Bile duct cancer (cholangiocarcinoma) is a rare but aggressive type of cancer that affects the bile duct system.
Symptoms of bile duct cancer may include jaundice, unintentional weight loss, and abdominal pain.
Risk factors for bile duct cancer include age (over 65), primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), bile duct abnormalities, biliary stones, parasitic infection, and exposure to toxins.
Treatment for bile duct cancer may involve surgery to remove the affected part of the bile duct, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or clinical trials of experimental treatments.
Binge eating disorder is characterized by regular episodes of overeating, often accompanied by feelings of guilt, shame, or disgust afterwards.

Symptoms of binge eating disorder include eating much faster than normal, eating until uncomfortably full, eating large amounts of food when not hungry, eating alone or secretly, and having feelings of guilt or shame afterwards.
Treatment options for binge eating disorder include guided self-help, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and antidepressant medication.
Binge eating can lead to weight gain and increase the risk of physical health problems such as high cholesterol, high blood pressure, diabetes, osteoarthritis, and certain types of cancer.
Bipolar disorder is a condition characterized by extreme mood swings, including periods of depression and mania.
Symptoms of depression in bipolar disorder include feeling sad or hopeless, lacking energy, difficulty concentrating, and thoughts of suicide.
Symptoms of mania in bipolar disorder include feeling very happy or elated, talking quickly, having lots of energy, and engaging in impulsive behaviors.

Treatment options for bipolar disorder include medication to stabilize mood, learning to recognize triggers and signs of episodes, psychological treatment, and lifestyle changes such as exercise and improving diet.
Bladder cancer is a growth of abnormal tissue in the bladder lining, which can spread into the surrounding muscles.
The most common symptom of bladder cancer is blood in the urine, which is usually painless.
Treatment for non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer may involve transurethral resection of a bladder tumor (TURBT) and chemotherapy.
Treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer may involve radical cystectomy (removal of the bladder) or radiotherapy with a radiosensitizer.
Sepsis is a serious complication of an infection that can lead to multiple organ failure and death if not treated quickly.
Sepsis can be caused by an infection in any part of the body, with common sites being the lungs, urinary tract, abdomen, and pelvis.
Diagnosis of sepsis involves testing temperature, heart rate, breathing rate, and blood, as well as other tests such as urine or stool samples and imaging studies.

People at higher risk of sepsis include the very young or old, pregnant individuals, those with weakened immune systems, and those with certain medical conditions or undergoing certain medical treatments.
Primary bone cancer is a rare type of cancer that starts in the bones.
The main symptoms of bone cancer include persistent bone pain, swelling and redness over a bone, a noticeable lump, and weak bones that break easily.
The main types of bone cancer are osteosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma, and chondrosarcoma.
Risk factors for bone cancer include previous radiation exposure, Paget's disease of the bone, and rare genetic conditions like Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
The two most common types of bone cancer in teenagers are osteosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma.
Osteosarcoma primarily affects bones in the leg, especially around the knee joint, but can occur in any bone.
Ewing sarcoma can affect any bone, but is most common in the pelvis or leg bones. It can also start in the soft tissue outside the bone.
The cause of bone cancer is unknown, but it is believed to be linked to changes that occur during bone growth.
Bowel cancer is a general term for cancer that begins in the large bowel and can be called colon or rectal cancer depending on where it starts.
The main symptoms of bowel cancer are blood in the stools, changes in bowel habit, and abdominal pain.
Risk factors for bowel cancer include age (most cases occur in people over 60), diet (high in red or processed meats and low in fiber), weight (being overweight or obese), and family history.
Treatment for bowel cancer can include surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and biological treatments.
Bowel incontinence, also known as faecal incontinence, is an inability to control bowel movements, resulting in involuntary soiling.

The experience of bowel incontinence can vary, with some people feeling a sudden need to go to the toilet but being unable to reach a toilet in time, while others may experience no sensation before soiling themselves.
Bowel incontinence can affect people of any age, but it is more common in elderly people and women.

Treatment for bowel incontinence can include lifestyle and dietary changes, exercise programs to strengthen the muscles that control the bowel, medication to control diarrhoea and constipation, and in some cases, surgery.
Bowel polyps are small growths on the inner lining of the colon or rectum and are common, affecting 15% to 20% of the UK population.
Most bowel polyps are less than 1cm in size and don't usually cause symptoms, but some larger polyps can cause rectal bleeding, mucus production, diarrhea or constipation, and abdominal pain.
Bowel polyps are usually discovered during a bowel investigation or screening for bowel cancer and can be removed through procedures like colonoscopy or CT colonography.

In rare cases, surgical removal of part of the bowel may be necessary if the polyp has cell changes or is particularly large. Regular colonoscopy checks may be needed to monitor for recurrence or development of new polyps.
Brain stem death is when a person permanently loses brain stem functions, including consciousness and the ability to breathe.
Brain death can occur when the blood and/or oxygen supply to the brain is stopped, such as during cardiac arrest or stroke.
Brain death is different from a vegetative state, as someone in a vegetative state still has a functioning brain stem and may have some form of consciousness.

Diagnosing brain stem death involves a series of tests, including checking for responses to light, touch, and cold water, as well as temporarily disconnecting the person from a ventilator to see if they attempt to breathe on their own.
A brain tumour is a growth of cells in the brain that multiplies in an abnormal, uncontrollable way.
Brain tumours are graded from 1 to 4 according to their behaviour, such as how fast they grow and how likely they are to grow back after treatment.

Benign brain tumours are low grade (grade 1 or 2), which means they grow slowly and are less likely to return after treatment. Malignant brain tumours are high grade (grade 3 or 4) and either start in the brain (primary tumours) or spread into the brain from elsewhere (secondary tumours); they're more likely to grow back after treatment.

The symptoms of a brain tumour vary depending on the exact part of the brain that's affected. Common symptoms include severe, persistent headaches, seizures (fits), persistent nausea, vomiting and drowsiness, mental or behavioural changes, such as memory problems or changes in personality, and progressive weakness or paralysis on one side of the body, vision problems, or speech problems.
Brain tumours are the most common tumours that develop in children, affecting boys slightly more often than girls.
Symptoms of brain tumours can include headaches, vomiting, seizures, changes in behavior, and problems with balance and coordination.
Brain tumours can be benign or malignant, with malignant tumours causing more damage and potentially spreading to other areas.
Treatment for brain tumours may include surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and medications to manage symptoms.
The brain is the control center of the body and is made up of the cerebrum, cerebellum, brain stem, and pituitary gland.
There are different types of brain tumors, including benign tumors that do not spread and malignant tumors that can spread to other parts of the brain or spinal cord.
Common symptoms of brain tumors include headaches, vomiting, seizures, changes in behavior, and problems with coordination and balance.
Treatment for brain tumors may include surgery to remove the tumor, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and supportive medications such as steroids and anticonvulsants.
Breast cancer is the most common type of cancer in the UK.
Most women who get breast cancer are over 50, but younger women and men can also get it.
Breast cancer can be prevented from spreading if treated early enough.
The main symptom of breast cancer is a lump or area of thickened breast tissue.
Breast cancer can also affect men, although it is much less common than in women.
The main symptom of breast cancer in men is a hard, painless lump in one of the breasts.
Other symptoms of male breast cancer may include nipple problems, such as retraction or discharge.
Treatment for male breast cancer may involve surgery, hormone-blocking therapy, radiotherapy, or chemotherapy.
Bronchiectasis is a long-term condition where the airways of the lungs become abnormally widened, leading to a build-up of excess mucus that can make the lungs more vulnerable to infection.
The most common symptoms of bronchiectasis include a persistent cough that usually brings up phlegm (sputum) and breathlessness.

Bronchiectasis can be caused by childhood lung infections, underlying problems with the immune system, allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), aspiration, cystic fibrosis, and cilia abnormalities.
Treatment for bronchiectasis may involve exercises and special devices to help clear mucus from the lungs, medication to improve airflow, and antibiotics to treat lung infections.
Bronchitis is an infection of the main airways of the lungs (bronchi), causing them to become irritated and inflamed.
The main symptom of bronchitis is a hacking cough, which may bring up thick yellow-grey mucus (phlegm).
Most cases of bronchitis can be treated at home with rest, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and plenty of fluids.
Chronic bronchitis, also known as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), is treated with medications to relieve symptoms and lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking.
The main symptoms of bulimia include bingeing, purging, a focus on food, and problems with self-esteem and body image.
Diagnosing bulimia involves questions about eating habits, weight, and concerns about weight, as well as physical examinations and blood tests.
Treatment for bulimia may involve guided self-help, structured psychological treatment, medication, and addressing complications such as dental problems and heart issues.
Seeking help for bulimia can involve talking to someone you trust, seeing a GP, or offering support to someone you know who may be experiencing bulimia.
Bunions (hallux valgus) are deformities caused by the base joint of the big toe developing sideways, pushing the bones towards the smaller toes.
Contributing factors to bunions include joint problems like osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, poorly fitting footwear, and a family history.
Symptoms of bunions include pain and stiffness in the big toe joint, swelling of the joint making it difficult to find wide enough shoes, and difficulty walking.

Management of bunions involves wearing well-fitting shoes with laces or adjustable straps, using insoles and toe spacers for support, taking pain medication, and doing exercises to strengthen foot muscles.
Carcinoid tumours are rare cancers of the neuroendocrine system that usually grow in the bowels or appendix but can also be found in other organs.

Carcinoid syndrome is a collection of symptoms that occur when a carcinoid tumour releases hormones into the bloodstream, causing symptoms such as diarrhea, flushing of the skin, fast heart rate, and breathlessness.

Symptoms caused by the tumour itself depend on the location of the tumour, such as tummy pain and bleeding from the bottom for bowel carcinoid tumours, and coughing up blood and chest pain for lung carcinoid tumours.

Treatment for carcinoid tumours may involve surgery to remove the tumour, injections of medicines to slow down tumour growth, radiotherapy, embolization, ablation, or chemotherapy. Symptoms of carcinoid syndrome can be managed with medication.
Catarrh is a build-up of mucus in an airway or cavity of the body.

Symptoms of catarrh include a constant need to clear your throat, feeling that your throat is blocked, blocked or stuffy nose, runny nose, feeling of mucus running down the back of your throat, persistent cough, headache or facial pain, reduced sense of smell and taste, and crackling sensation in your ear and temporary hearing loss.
Home remedies for catarrh include avoiding triggers, drinking cold water, using a saline nasal rinse, avoiding warm and dry atmospheres, staying hydrated, and using over-the-counter medications.

Catarrh is usually caused by an infection or irritation, such as a cold, allergies, non-allergic rhinitis, or nasal polyps. The cause of chronic catarrh is unclear but may be related to abnormal mucus travel or increased sensitivity.
Cellulitis is an infection of the deeper layers of skin and underlying tissue that can be serious if not treated promptly.
Symptoms of cellulitis include redness, swelling, pain, and tenderness in the affected area, and in severe cases, it can be accompanied by a high temperature, shaking, nausea, and confusion.
Cellulitis is usually caused by a bacterial infection that enters the skin through a break, such as a cut, bite, or ulcer.
Treatment for cellulitis typically involves antibiotics, with most cases being treated at home, although severe infections may require hospitalization.
Cerebral palsy is a condition caused by damage or abnormal development of the brain before birth or during early development.
The main types of abnormal muscle tone in cerebral palsy are spastic, dyskinetic, ataxic, and mixed.
Symptoms of cerebral palsy can include difficulties with movement, speech, eating, vision, and learning, as well as fatigue, epilepsy, and behavioral problems.
Cerebral palsy can be caused by factors such as premature birth, neonatal encephalopathy, stroke, infection, and head injuries.
Cervical cancer is a type of cancer that develops in a woman's cervix.
Symptoms of cervical cancer may include unusual vaginal bleeding, pain during sex, and an unpleasant smelling vaginal discharge.
Almost all cases of cervical cancer are caused by the human papilloma virus (HPV), which is spread through sexual contact.
Treatment for cervical cancer may include surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy.
The main symptoms of a chest infection include a persistent cough, coughing up phlegm, breathlessness, wheezing, high temperature, rapid heartbeat, chest pain, and confusion.
Chest infections are usually caused by viruses or bacteria and can be spread through coughing, sneezing, or touching contaminated surfaces.
Certain groups of people, such as babies, the elderly, pregnant women, and those with underlying health conditions, are at a higher risk of developing serious chest infections.

Treatment for chest infections at home includes rest, staying hydrated, using pain relief for symptoms, and avoiding cough medicines. Antibiotics are only prescribed for bacterial infections or high-risk cases.
Chest pain can be caused by a heart attack, which occurs when the blood supply to part of the heart is blocked.
Angina is another cause of chest pain, where the blood supply to the muscles of the heart is restricted.
Pulmonary embolism, a blockage in the blood vessel that carries blood from the heart to the lungs, can cause sharp, stabbing chest pain.
Pericarditis, inflammation of the sac surrounding the heart, can cause sudden, sharp chest pain that worsens when lying down.
Chickenpox is a mild and common illness that mostly affects children but can be caught at any age.
Chickenpox is caused by a virus called the varicella-zoster virus and is spread quickly and easily from someone who is infected.
The main symptom of chickenpox is a rash of red, itchy spots that turn into fluid-filled blisters and then crust over.
Treatment for chickenpox involves managing symptoms with remedies such as paracetamol and calamine lotion, and keeping children off school or nursery until all spots have crusted over.
Chilblains are small, itchy swellings on the skin that occur as a reaction to cold temperatures.
Chilblains usually develop several hours after exposure to the cold and can cause a burning and itching sensation in the affected areas.
In severe cases, chilblains can cause the skin to blister and may lead to infection.
Treatment for chilblains often involves using soothing lotions to relieve itching and, in severe cases, taking medication to improve circulation and prevent further development.
Chlamydia is a common bacterial infection and one of the most common sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in the UK.

Symptoms of chlamydia may include pain when peeing, unusual discharge from the vagina, penis or anus, pain in the lower tummy, bleeding after sex, bleeding between periods, pain in the testicles, and red, sticky eyes.
Testing for chlamydia can be done by booking an appointment at a sexual health service, contacting a GP practice, or ordering a home test kit.
Chlamydia can be treated with antibiotics, and it is important to avoid having sex until 1 week after treatment to prevent spreading the infection.
Myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME) or chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is a long term neurological condition that affects the nervous and immune systems.
People with ME/CFS experience severe pain and fatigue associated with post-exertional malaise (PEM), which is the body's inability to recover after using even small amounts of energy.

Symptoms of ME/CFS include feeling generally unwell, pain, broken sleep, problems with concentration and memory, poor temperature control, dizziness, sensitivity to light and sound, nausea, loss of appetite, and muscle pain.
There is no single test to detect ME/CFS, and a diagnosis is made after other possible causes for symptoms have been excluded.
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a long-term condition where the kidneys do not work effectively.
Symptoms of advanced kidney disease include tiredness, swollen ankles, shortness of breath, nausea, and blood in the urine.
CKD is most frequently diagnosed through blood and urine tests, and screening is recommended for those at high risk, such as people with high blood pressure or diabetes.
Treatment for CKD may involve lifestyle changes, medication for high blood pressure and cholesterol, and in some cases, dialysis or a kidney transplant.
Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is a type of cancer that affects the white blood cells and progresses slowly over many years.

Symptoms of CLL may include frequent infections, persistent tiredness, easy bruising or bleeding, high temperature, night sweats, swollen glands, swelling and discomfort in the abdomen, and unintentional weight loss.

Treatment for CLL depends on the stage of the condition and may include chemotherapy, stem cell or bone marrow transplant, radiotherapy, surgery, and medications to prevent infections or boost white blood cell production.

Complications of CLL can include infections, Richter's syndrome (a transformation into an aggressive form of lymphoma), autoimmune haemolytic anaemia, and psychological effects such as anxiety and depression.
Chronic myeloid leukaemia is a cancer of the myeloid cells, which are responsible for fighting bacterial infections and preventing tissue damage.
Early symptoms of chronic myeloid leukaemia include tiredness, weight loss, night sweats, bloating, bruising, and bone pain.
Chronic myeloid leukaemia is more common in people aged 40 to 60 and is not inherited.
Treatment for chronic myeloid leukaemia includes imatinib tablets to slow the progression of the cancer and chemotherapy for advanced stages.
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a collection of lung diseases including chronic bronchitis, emphysema, and chronic obstructive airways disease.
Symptoms of COPD include increasing breathlessness when active, a persistent cough with phlegm, and frequent chest infections.
The main cause of COPD is smoking, but exposure to fumes, dust, air pollution, and genetic factors can also contribute to its development.
Treatment for COPD includes stopping smoking, using inhalers to relieve symptoms, taking medication to reduce inflammation, and participating in pulmonary rehabilitation programs.
Chronic or persistent pain refers to pain that lasts longer than 12 weeks.
It can extend beyond the natural healing time of an injury or condition.
Chronic or persistent pain can be caused by various factors such as nerve damage, inflammation, or underlying medical conditions.
Treatment for chronic or persistent pain may involve a combination of medication, physical therapy, and lifestyle changes.
Chronic pancreatitis is a condition where the pancreas becomes permanently damaged from inflammation.
The most common symptom of chronic pancreatitis is repeated episodes of abdominal pain.
Chronic pancreatitis can be caused by long-term alcohol misuse, smoking, immune system problems, or genetic mutations.
Treatment for chronic pancreatitis focuses on lifestyle changes, medication for pain relief, and in severe cases, surgery.
Cirrhosis is scarring of the liver caused by continuous, long-term liver damage.
The damage caused by cirrhosis can't be reversed and can eventually become so extensive that your liver stops functioning. This is called liver failure.
Each year in the UK, around 4,000 people die from cirrhosis and 700 people with the condition need a liver transplant to survive.
There are usually few symptoms in the early stages of cirrhosis. However, as your liver loses its ability to function properly, you're likely to experience a loss of appetite, nausea and itchy skin.
Clostridium difficile, also known as C. difficile or C. diff, is a bacterium that can infect the bowel and cause diarrhoea.
Symptoms of a C. difficile infection include watery diarrhoea, painful tummy cramps, feeling sick, signs of dehydration, a high temperature, and loss of appetite and weight loss.

People most at risk of C. difficile are those who have been treated with antibiotics, have stayed in a healthcare setting for a long time, are over 65 years old, have certain underlying conditions, have a weakened immune system, are taking a proton pump inhibitor, or have had surgery on their digestive system.

Treatment for C. difficile can include stopping the antibiotics causing the infection, taking antibiotics that kill C. difficile bacteria, and in severe cases, surgery to remove a damaged section of the bowel.
Coeliac disease is an autoimmune condition where the immune system in a person's intestine reacts to gluten, causing chronic inflammation.
Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, and is present in many common foods and drinks.
Coeliac disease affects 1 in every 100 people, with reported cases being more common in women than men.
Symptoms of coeliac disease can vary and may include severe diarrhea, stomach pain, iron deficiency, fatigue, weight loss, mouth ulcers, and neurological problems.
Cold sores are small blisters that develop on the lips or around the mouth and are caused by the herpes simplex virus.
Cold sores usually clear up without treatment within 7 to 10 days.
The herpes simplex virus is highly contagious and can be easily passed from person to person by close direct contact.
Cold sores can be treated with antiviral creams or tablets to ease symptoms and speed up healing time.
A coma is a state of unconsciousness where a person is unresponsive and cannot be woken.
Comas can result from brain injuries, such as severe head injuries or strokes, as well as severe alcohol poisoning or brain infections.
People with diabetes can fall into a coma if their blood glucose levels become very low (hypoglycemia) or very high (hyperglycemia).
Caring for someone in a coma involves constant monitoring of their level of consciousness using the Glasgow Coma Scale and providing supportive treatment in an intensive care unit.
The main symptoms of a cold include a sore throat, a blocked or runny nose, sneezing, and a cough.
Less common symptoms of a cold include a high temperature (fever), a headache, earache, and muscle aches.
Speak to your GP if your symptoms do not improve after 3 weeks, your symptoms get suddenly worse, or you're concerned about your child's symptoms.
There's no cure for a cold, but you can rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take over-the-counter pain relief to relieve symptoms.
The most common heart condition in Scotland is coronary heart disease, which is caused when the heart's blood vessels become narrowed or blocked and can't supply enough blood to the heart.
Angina is a symptom of coronary heart disease and is characterized by pain or discomfort in the chest, arm, neck, stomach, or jaw due to restricted blood supply to the heart.
Unstable angina is a sudden worsening of existing angina, with angina attacks occurring more frequently and with less activity. It may even occur at rest or wake you from sleep.
A heart attack, or myocardial infarction, occurs when the blood supply to part of the heart muscle becomes completely blocked, usually due to a blood clot forming within a coronary artery.
Congenital heart disease is a general term used to refer to a series of birth defects that affect the heart.
The two main types of congenital heart disease are cyanotic heart disease and acyanotic heart disease.

Cyanotic heart disease is characterized by a lack of oxygen in the blood, resulting in a blue-colored tinge to areas such as the fingers, toes, and lips, as well as symptoms such as breathlessness, chest pain, and fatigue.
Acyanotic heart disease is characterized by abnormal blood flow in the body, leading to symptoms such as severe tiredness, palpitations, and shortness of breath.
Conjunctivitis usually causes symptoms in both eyes like inflammation, redness, itching, a burning or gritty feeling, watering, and pus that sticks to the eyelashes.

The three most common causes of conjunctivitis are infection (infective conjunctivitis), an allergic reaction (allergic conjunctivitis), and something irritating the conjunctiva, like a loose eyelash (irritant conjunctivitis).
Treatment for conjunctivitis may include cleaning off crusts with a cotton wool pad, using lubricant eye drops, and avoiding rubbing the eyes or wearing contact lenses.
If you experience pain in your eyes, sensitivity to light, changes in vision, very red eyes, or have a baby less than 28 days old with red eyes, it is important to seek urgent medical attention.
Constipation is a common condition that affects people of all ages, characterized by infrequent or difficult bowel movements.
The main symptoms of constipation include infrequent bowel movements, difficulty passing stools, and stools that are hard and lumpy.
Causes of constipation can include a lack of fiber in the diet, changes in routine or lifestyle, ignoring the urge to pass stools, certain medications, and not drinking enough fluids.

Treatment for constipation often involves making dietary and lifestyle changes, such as increasing fiber intake, drinking plenty of fluids, and exercising regularly. Laxatives may also be recommended in some cases.
Vaccinations are effective at preventing serious illness from coronavirus.

Symptoms of coronavirus include continuous cough, high temperature, loss of taste or smell, shortness of breath, fatigue, muscle aches, headache, sore throat, stuffy or runny nose, diarrhea, and nausea or vomiting.
To help with symptoms, drink fluids, get plenty of rest, wear comfortable clothing, and take over-the-counter medications like paracetamol.
To reduce the spread of infection, work from home if possible, wear a well-fitting face covering, regularly clean frequently touched surfaces, and wash hands regularly.
A cough is a reflex action to clear your airways of mucus and irritants such as dust or smoke.
Most coughs clear up within 3 weeks and don't require any treatment.
Common causes of a short-term cough include upper respiratory tract infections, lower respiratory tract infections, allergies, and inhaled dust or smoke.

A persistent cough may be caused by long-term respiratory tract infections, asthma, allergies, smoking, bronchiectasis, postnasal drip, gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD), or certain medications.
Crohn's disease is a long-term condition that causes inflammation of the lining of the digestive system.
Common symptoms of Crohn's disease include recurring diarrhea, abdominal pain and cramping, extreme tiredness, unintended weight loss, and blood and mucus in the stool.
The exact cause of Crohn's disease is unknown, but it may be caused by a combination of genetics, immune system problems, environmental factors, and smoking.
Treatment for Crohn's disease may include steroid medication, medicines to suppress the immune system, biological therapies, surgery, and dietary changes.
Croup is a childhood condition that affects the windpipe, airways to the lungs, and voice box.
Symptoms of croup include a bark-like cough, hoarse voice, difficulty breathing, and a harsh grating sound when breathing in.
Croup is usually caused by a viral infection, most commonly the parainfluenza virus.

Treatment for croup may involve managing symptoms at home with pain relief medication, ensuring hydration, and using oral corticosteroids to reduce swelling in the throat. Severe cases may require hospital treatment with adrenaline and oxygen.
Cystic fibrosis is an inherited condition that causes the lungs and digestive system to become clogged with thick, sticky mucus.
Symptoms of cystic fibrosis can include recurring chest infections, difficulty putting on weight, frequent wet-sounding coughs, diarrhea, and occasional wheezing and shortness of breath.
Cystic fibrosis is caused by a faulty gene that a child inherits from both parents, resulting in a build-up of mucus in the body's tubes and passageways.
Treatment for cystic fibrosis may include antibiotics to prevent and treat chest infections, medications to make mucus thinner, airway clearance techniques, and dietary and nutritional advice.
Cystitis is inflammation of the bladder, usually caused by a bladder infection.

The main symptoms of cystitis include pain, burning or stinging when you pee, needing to pee more often and urgently than normal, urine that's dark, cloudy or strong smelling, and pain low down in your tummy.

Cystitis can be caused by bacteria entering the bladder through the urethra, which can happen during sex, wiping from back to front after going to the toilet, inserting a tampon or urinary catheter, or using a diaphragm for contraception.
Treatment for cystitis may involve antibiotics, over-the-counter painkillers, drinking plenty of water, using a hot water bottle, and avoiding sex until symptoms improve.
Deafblindness is a combination of sight and hearing loss that affects a person's ability to communicate, access information and get around.
Signs of deafblindness can include difficulty following a conversation, not hearing noises such as a knock at the door, and needing to hold books or newspapers very close.
Deafblindness can be caused by age-related hearing loss, genetic conditions, infections during pregnancy, cerebral palsy, and eye problems associated with increasing age.
Treatment for deafblindness may involve preserving and maximizing remaining sight or hearing, teaching alternative methods of communication, and helping the person retain or develop independence.
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a blood clot that develops within a deep vein in the body, usually in the leg.
Symptoms of DVT may include pain, swelling, tenderness, warm skin, and redness in the affected leg.
DVT can lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism, which occurs when a blood clot travels to the lungs and blocks a blood vessel.
Treatment for DVT usually involves taking anticoagulant medicines, wearing compression stockings, and making lifestyle changes to reduce the risk of recurrence.
Dehydration occurs when your body loses more fluid than you take in.
Some early warning signs of dehydration include feeling thirsty and lightheaded, having a dry mouth, feeling tired, and passing urine less often than usual.
Dehydration can be caused by not drinking enough fluid, sweating from fever or physical activity, or an illness like gastroenteritis.
The groups most at risk for dehydration are babies and infants, older people, people with long-term health conditions, and athletes.
Dementia is a common condition that usually occurs in people over the age of 65.
The risk of developing dementia increases as you get older.
There are causes and possible preventions for dementia.
Treatment options for dementia include organizing care, care homes, and managing legal affairs.
Dementia with Lewy bodies is a common form of dementia that affects more than 100,000 people in the UK.
Symptoms of dementia with Lewy bodies include problems with memory, judgement, concentration, visual perception, and extreme swings between alertness and drowsiness.
The condition is caused by deposits of an abnormal protein called Lewy bodies in the brain, which disrupt normal brain functions.
There is no cure for dementia with Lewy bodies, but treatments can help manage symptoms, including medication and supportive therapies.
A dental abscess is a collection of pus that can form inside the teeth, in the gums, or in the bone that holds the teeth in place.

Symptoms of a dental abscess may include intense, throbbing pain in the affected tooth or gum, pain that spreads to the ear, jaw, and neck, redness and swelling in the face, and sensitivity to hot or cold food and drink.
It's important to seek dental help as soon as possible if you think you have a dental abscess, as they don't go away on their own and can spread to other parts of the body.

Treatments for a dental abscess may include removing the affected tooth, root canal treatment, or incision and drainage to drain the abscess. Antibiotics may be used if the infection spreads or is severe.
Depression is a real condition that affects around one in 10 people and can make you feel persistently sad and down for weeks or months at a time.
Symptoms of depression include feeling tearful, losing interest in things, feeling guilty, feeling anxious, and thinking about suicide.
Depression can be caused by stressful life events, illness, job loss, or money worries, and can also be influenced by genetics and family history.
Treatment for depression may involve talking therapies such as cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), medication such as antidepressants, and social support.
Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) affects around 1 in 10,000 people and is most commonly diagnosed in those between the ages of 15 and 40. It is more common in men than women and is rare in children.

Symptoms of DH include red, raised patches often with blisters that burst with scratching, severe itching and stinging. The rash usually occurs on the elbows, knees, and buttocks, and can affect any area of the skin.

Most people with DH have the same kind of gut damage seen with coeliac disease, but may not experience gut symptoms such as diarrhea, constipation, stomach pain, or bloating. Just over half of people with DH don't have gut symptoms.

DH is caused by the body's immune system reacting to gluten in foods containing wheat, barley, and rye. A diagnosis of DH is confirmed by a skin biopsy, and blood tests may also be taken for coeliac disease.
Diabetes is a lifelong condition that causes a person's blood glucose (sugar) level to become too high.
There are two main types of diabetes ' type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes.
Type 2 diabetes is far more common than type 1. In the UK, around 90% of all adults with diabetes have type 2.
There are 4.7 million people living with diabetes in the UK. That's more than one in 15 people in the UK who has diabetes (diagnosed or undiagnosed).
Diarrhoea is passing looser, watery or more frequent poo (stools) than is normal for you.
Diarrhoea can be caused by a bowel infection (gastroenteritis) from viruses, bacteria, or parasites.
Most cases of diarrhoea clear up after a few days without treatment, but it's important to drink plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration.
To prevent spreading infection, stay at home until at least 48 hours after the last episode of diarrhoea.
Discoid eczema is a long-term skin condition that causes circular or oval patches of itchy, reddened, swollen, and cracked skin.
The patches can be a few millimeters to a few centimeters in size and can appear anywhere on the body except the face and scalp.
The patches may initially be swollen, blistered, and ooze fluid, but over time they become dry, crusty, cracked, and flaky.
Treatment for discoid eczema may include emollients, topical corticosteroids, antihistamines, and in severe cases, oral corticosteroids.
Diverticular disease is characterized by the development of small bulges or pockets (diverticula) in the lining of the large intestine.
Symptoms of diverticular disease include lower abdominal pain and bloating.
Diverticulitis occurs when the diverticula become inflamed or infected, causing more severe symptoms such as constant and severe abdominal pain, high temperature, and diarrhea.
Treatment options for diverticular disease and diverticulitis include a high-fiber diet, pain relief medication, antibiotics, and in severe cases, surgery.
Dizziness (lightheadedness) is a common symptom that should be investigated by a doctor.
The term "dizziness" can refer to feeling lightheaded or off balance, or feeling like the surroundings are spinning.
Dizziness can have a wide range of causes, making it difficult to identify the underlying cause.

Common causes of dizziness include inner ear infections, migraines, stress or anxiety, low blood sugar levels, postural hypotension, dehydration or heat exhaustion, and decreased blood flow in the back of the brain.
Down's syndrome, also known as Trisomy 21, is a genetic condition where a person is born with an extra copy of chromosome 21.
People with Down's syndrome can lead active and independent lives, with many living into their 60s, 70s, and beyond.
Most individuals with Down's syndrome have mild to moderate learning disabilities, although some may have more complex needs.

Regular health checks are important for individuals with Down's syndrome, as they may have certain health conditions such as heart issues, muscle tone and digestion issues, and reduced hearing or vision.
Contact your dentist or GP if you have a persistently dry mouth and experience difficulty chewing, swallowing, or talking.
A dry mouth can be caused by dehydration, anxiety, medication, a blocked nose, diabetes, radiotherapy, or Sj'gren's syndrome.
A dry mouth can lead to problems such as a burning sensation, dry lips, bad breath, reduced sense of taste, mouth infections, tooth decay, and difficulty speaking or eating.
Treatment for a dry mouth may involve addressing the underlying cause, adjusting medication, using artificial saliva substitutes, or taking medication to stimulate salivary gland production.
Dysphagia is the medical term for swallowing difficulties.
Signs of dysphagia include coughing or choking when eating or drinking, bringing food back up, a sensation of food stuck in the throat or chest, and persistent drooling of saliva.
Dysphagia can be caused by conditions that affect the nervous system, cancer, or gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD).
Treatment for dysphagia may include swallowing therapy, dietary changes, and feeding tubes.
Dystonia is a neurological movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle spasms and contractions.
Symptoms of dystonia can include uncontrolled muscle spasms, twisting of body parts into unusual positions, shaking (tremors), and excessive blinking.
There are different types of dystonia, including generalized dystonia that affects all parts of the body and focal dystonia that affects only one muscle group.
Dystonia can be caused by a problem with the part of the brain that controls movement and can be primary (with a genetic cause) or secondary (as a symptom of another condition).
Earache is a common problem, particularly in children, and is usually caused by a minor infection.
Symptoms of earache can include sharp, dull, or burning ear pain that comes and goes or is constant, and may affect one or both ears.

Medical advice should be sought if earache is accompanied by a high temperature (fever), vomiting, severe sore throat, hearing loss, swelling around the ear, discharge from the ear, something stuck in the ear, or if the earache doesn't improve within a few days.
Treatment for earache may involve using over-the-counter painkillers, warm flannels against the affected ear, and avoiding putting objects in the ear or getting the affected ear wet.
A build-up of earwax in your ear can cause earache, hearing loss, tinnitus, itchiness in or around the ear, and ear infections.
Eardrops bought from a pharmacy can often treat a build-up of earwax.
Do not try to remove a build-up of earwax yourself with your fingers or any other object, as this can damage your ear.
If eardrops haven't helped after 1 week, speak to your GP practice.
Ebola virus disease is a serious illness that originated in Africa and had a large outbreak in 2014 to 2015.
The 2014 to 2015 outbreak mainly affected Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, with some cases in central Africa.
The outbreak resulted in around 28,000 cases and over 11,000 deaths, making it the largest known outbreak of Ebola.

The risk of Ebola in Africa is still present, but the risk for people traveling to Africa is minimal, with the highest risk being for those who care for infected individuals or handle their blood or fluid.
An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg develops outside the womb, typically in one of the fallopian tubes.
Symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy may include pain on one side of the abdomen, vaginal bleeding, shoulder pain, discomfort during urination, and brown watery discharge.
An ectopic pregnancy puts the woman's health at risk and requires prompt medical attention.
Treatment for an ectopic pregnancy involves surgical removal or medication prescribed by a doctor.
Edwards' syndrome (trisomy 18) is a genetic condition that affects babies in the womb and throughout their life.
There are three forms of Edwards' syndrome: full form, mosaic form, and partial form.
Most cases of Edwards' syndrome result from random changes in the egg or sperm.
Babies with Edwards' syndrome may have associated health conditions, including heart issues, seizures, hearing loss, joint contractures, and cleft lip and/or palate.
Epilepsy is a condition that affects the brain and is defined by repeated seizures.
The main symptoms of epilepsy are repeated seizures, which can vary in severity and type depending on which part of the brain is affected.
There are different types of seizures, including focal seizures (where only a small part of the brain is affected) and generalized seizures (where most or all of the brain is affected).
Epilepsy can be caused by various factors, including structural abnormalities in the brain, genetic abnormalities, infections, autoimmune conditions, or unknown causes.
Erectile dysfunction (ED) is the inability to get and maintain an erection for satisfactory intercourse.
ED can be caused by physical conditions such as cardiovascular disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, and hormonal problems.
Psychological causes of ED include anxiety, depression, and relationship problems.
Treatment options for ED include lifestyle changes, medication (such as PDE-5 inhibitors), vacuum pumps, alprostadil injections, surgery, psychological therapies, and pelvic floor muscle exercises.
Escherichia coli O157, also known as VTEC, is a bacterial infection that can cause severe stomach pain, bloody diarrhea, and kidney failure.

E. coli O157 is commonly found in the gut and feces of animals, particularly cattle, and can be contracted through consuming contaminated food, touching infected animals or their feces, contact with infected individuals, drinking untreated water, or swimming in contaminated water.
Symptoms of E. coli O157 infection include diarrhea, stomach cramps, fever, and occasionally bloody diarrhea, with symptoms appearing 3 to 4 days after infection and lasting up to 2 weeks.

In some cases, E. coli O157 infection can lead to a serious condition called haemolytic uraemic syndrome (HUS), which can result in kidney failure and death, although this is rare. The risk of HUS is highest in children under 5 years of age.
Ewing sarcoma is a rare type of bone cancer that most commonly affects people who are 10 to 20 years old.
The main symptoms of Ewing sarcoma are pain in the affected area that gets progressively worse, swelling, tenderness, and in some cases, a high temperature, severe tiredness, and weight loss.
The exact cause of Ewing sarcoma is unknown, but it may be related to fast-growing bones during puberty and an increased risk has been found in babies born with an umbilical hernia.
Treatment for Ewing sarcoma usually involves a combination of chemotherapy, surgery, and radiotherapy, with the type of surgery depending on the size and location of the tumor.
Ewing sarcoma is a type of bone cancer that primarily affects children and young people.
The most common symptom of Ewing sarcoma is pain, which is often worse at night and may be accompanied by swelling and tenderness in the affected area.
Diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma involves various tests and investigations, such as X-rays, biopsies, and scans.
Treatment options for Ewing sarcoma include chemotherapy, surgery (such as limb-sparing surgery or amputation), and radiotherapy.
Eye cancer can include different types such as eye melanoma, squamous cell carcinoma, lymphoma, and retinoblastoma.

Symptoms of eye cancer may include shadows or flashes of light in vision, blurred vision, a dark patch in the eye, partial or total loss of vision, bulging of one eye, a lump on the eyelid or in the eye, and rare cases of eye pain.
Melanoma of the eye, also known as uveal or choroidal melanoma, is one of the most common types of eye cancer and can affect the eyeball, conjunctiva, or eyelid.
Risk factors for eye melanoma include lighter eye color, white or pale skin, unusual moles, use of sunbeds, overexposure to sunlight, and increasing age.
Febrile seizures are fits that can happen when a child has a fever.
They most often occur between the ages of six months and three years.
During a febrile seizure, the child's body becomes stiff, they lose consciousness, and their arms and legs twitch.
Febrile seizures are often associated with viral infections such as chickenpox, flu, middle ear infections, and tonsillitis.
Globus is a symptom that can make you feel like you have a lump in your throat, also known as "globus sensation".
Symptoms of globus may include tightness or pressure in the throat, mucus that cannot be cleared, discomfort in the throat, and a feeling of something stuck or a lump in the throat.
If you experience difficulty or pain when swallowing, a lump in the neck, unintentional weight loss, or if your symptoms do not improve, it is recommended to speak to your GP.
Self-help tips for relieving globus symptoms include drinking enough water, avoiding alcohol and certain foods, not clearing the throat, maintaining a healthy weight, and reducing stress.
A fever is when your body temperature is 37.8'C or higher and can be a symptom of common illnesses such as flu, tonsillitis, and kidney or urinary tract infections (UTIs).

Contact your GP practice immediately if you have a fever and are on treatment for immune deficiency, immune-suppressant drugs, or have certain medical conditions such as cancer, HIV, or chronic lung disease.
Contact your GP practice if you have severe thirst, dark urine, weakness, new symptoms, or have had a fever after recent foreign travel.
To treat a fever, wear loose comfortable clothing, keep the room temperature cool, drink plenty of fluids, and take a fever-reducing medicine like paracetamol.
Most fevers in children are caused by infections or other illnesses, such as upper respiratory tract infections, flu, ear infections, and tonsillitis.
Seek medical help if your child is under 3 months and has a temperature of 38'C (101'F) or above, or if they have a high temperature that's lasted for 5 days or more.
Keep your child hydrated by giving them plenty of cool water to drink when they have a fever.
Children's paracetamol or ibuprofen can be used to reduce fever, but always follow the correct dose and frequency for your child's age.
The main symptom of fibromyalgia is widespread pain that can feel like an ache, burning sensation, sharp stabbing pain, or a combination of these feelings.

People with fibromyalgia may also experience increased sensitivity to touch, light, temperature, and noise, fatigue, muscle stiffness, difficulty sleeping, problems with memory and concentration, headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, dizziness, restless legs syndrome, and tingling or numbness in the hands and feet.
The exact cause of fibromyalgia is unknown, but it is likely that changes in the central nervous system, genetics, and triggers such as injuries, infections, or stressful events play a role.

There is no specific test to diagnose fibromyalgia, but certain criteria, including widespread pain, consistent symptoms for at least 3 months, unrefreshing sleep, cognitive difficulties, and fatigue, are used for diagnosis.
Farting (flatulence) is passing gas from the digestive system out of the back passage.

Excessive farting can be caused by swallowing more air than usual, eating foods that are difficult to digest, conditions affecting the digestive system like indigestion or irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), and some medicines like non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), statins, and some laxatives.

To reduce excessive or smelly farting, chew food slowly with your mouth closed, eat smaller meals more often, drink slowly, exercise regularly to improve digestion, eat foods that are easy to digest like rice, bananas, citrus fruits, and potatoes, and drink peppermint tea.
A pharmacist can give you advice about excessive or smelly farts and may recommend charcoal tablets or special underwear or pads that absorb smells.

The main symptoms of flu (influenza) include a sudden high temperature, tiredness and weakness, a headache, general aches and pains, a dry, chesty cough, sore throat, difficulty sleeping, loss of appetite, diarrhea or tummy pain, feeling sick and being sick, chills, a runny or blocked nose, and sneezing.
The symptoms of flu usually develop 1 to 3 days after becoming infected and most people will feel better within a week, but may have a lingering cough and feel tired for a few more weeks.

If you have symptoms of flu and are worried about your baby's or child's symptoms, are 65 or over, are pregnant, have a long-term medical condition, have a weakened immune system, or your symptoms don't improve after 7 days, you should phone 111 or ask for an urgent GP appointment.

To treat flu at home, it is recommended to rest, get plenty of sleep, keep warm, drink lots of water to avoid dehydration, take paracetamol or ibuprofen to lower temperature and treat aches and pains, and stay off work or school until feeling better.
Food poisoning is an illness caused by eating contaminated food and is usually not serious, with most people recovering within a few days without treatment.
Common causes of food poisoning include bacteria such as campylobacter, salmonella, Escherichia coli (E. coli), and viruses like norovirus and listeria.
Symptoms of food poisoning include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (which may contain blood or mucus), stomach cramps, weakness, loss of appetite, fever, muscle aches, and chills.

If you have food poisoning, it is recommended to stay off school or work until you have not been sick or had diarrhea for at least 2 days, rest, drink plenty of water, consider an oral rehydration solution, eat small, light meals, and avoid alcohol, caffeine, fizzy drinks, spice, and fatty foods.
Functional neurological disorder (FND) is a condition where there is a problem with how the brain sends and receives information to the rest of the body.

FND can cause a range of symptoms, including limb weakness, seizures, tremors, dystonia, gait disorder, facial spasms, tics, cognitive difficulties, speech and swallowing problems, dizziness, visual symptoms, and dissociative symptoms.
The causes of FND can vary and may include the brain trying to get rid of a painful sensation, migraines, or the brain shutting down in response to a perceived threat.
Treatment for FND may involve physiotherapy, occupational therapy, psychological therapy, speech and language therapy, and medication to manage symptoms such as pain, depression, and anxiety.
Many people develop a fungal nail infection at some point in their life.
The infection develops slowly and causes the nail to become discoloured, thickened and distorted.
Toenails are more frequently affected than the fingernails.
The medical name for a fungal nail infection is onychomycosis.
Gallbladder cancer is a rare form of cancer that affects the gallbladder, with over 85% of cases being adenocarcinoma.
Symptoms of gallbladder cancer can include abdominal pain, nausea, and jaundice.
Gallbladder cancer is more common in older people and is associated with factors such as obesity, smoking, and certain medical conditions like gallstones and cholecystitis.
Treatment for gallbladder cancer typically involves surgery to remove the gallbladder, along with possible chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
Gallstones are small stones that form in the gallbladder and usually don't cause symptoms.
Symptoms of gallstones can include sudden intense abdominal pain, known as biliary colic, as well as persistent pain, jaundice, and fever.
Gallstones can lead to complications such as inflammation of the gallbladder (cholecystitis), infection of the bile ducts (cholangitis), acute pancreatitis, and gallbladder cancer.
Treatment for gallstones may involve pain management, surgical removal of the gallbladder, or procedures to remove the stones from the bile ducts.
Ganglion cysts are soft, gel-like masses that often change size.
Ganglion cysts are the most common type of swelling in the hand, wrist, and foot.
Ganglion cysts are usually harmless and can safely be left alone.
Ganglion cysts can be caused by a leak of fluid from a joint or tendon tunnel, and the cause of the leak is generally unknown.
Gastroenteritis is a common condition that causes diarrhoea and vomiting, usually caused by a bacterial or viral tummy bug.
The main symptoms of gastroenteritis are sudden, watery diarrhoea, feeling sick, vomiting (which can be projectile), and a mild fever.
Treatment for gastroenteritis involves staying at home until you're feeling better, drinking plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration, taking paracetamol for fever and aches, and getting plenty of rest.
If you have severe symptoms, such as severe dehydration, bloody diarrhoea, constant vomiting, a high fever, or symptoms that don't improve after a few days, you should seek medical advice.
Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) is a common condition where acid from the stomach leaks up into the oesophagus.
Symptoms of GORD include heartburn, acid reflux, oesophagitis, bad breath, bloating and belching, feeling or being sick, and pain when swallowing.
GORD can often be controlled with self-help measures and medication, but surgery may be needed in some cases.
Complications of GORD can include oesophageal ulcers, a scarred and narrow oesophagus, Barrett's oesophagus, and oesophageal cancer.
Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) and can cause painful blisters and sores on and around the genitals.
Symptoms of genital herpes may include spots or red bumps around the genital area, pain during urination, fever, and flu-like symptoms.
Genital herpes can be diagnosed by a doctor or nurse through visual examination or by taking a swab for testing.
Treatment for genital herpes involves antiviral medication to manage symptoms and reduce the frequency of recurrent episodes.
Not all symptoms around the genitals are caused by sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
Symptoms such as severe pain, high temperature, and nausea/vomiting may indicate a serious illness and require immediate medical attention.
Ulcers on the genitals can be a sign of recent syphilis infection or other infections/trauma.
Pelvic pain may be caused by various factors, including STIs like gonorrhea or chlamydia, and should be discussed with a healthcare provider.
Genital warts are small, rough lumps on the skin that can appear around the vagina, penis, anus, or the skin between the genitals and anus.
Symptoms of genital warts may include painless lumps or growths, itching or bleeding from the genitals or anus, or having a sexual partner with genital warts.
Testing for genital warts involves an examination of the genital area by a doctor or nurse.
Treatment options for genital warts include cream or liquid application, freezing, or surgery.
Most children who develop germ cell tumours will be cured.
Germ cell tumours can appear at any age and develop from cells that produce eggs or sperm.
Germ cell tumours may be non-cancerous (benign) or cancerous (malignant) and can spread to other parts of the body.
Treatment for germ cell tumours usually includes surgery or chemotherapy, depending on the size, position, and stage of the tumour.
Glandular fever, also known as infectious mononucleosis or 'mono', is a viral infection that mostly affects young adults.
Common symptoms of glandular fever include a high temperature (fever), a severely sore throat, swollen glands in the neck, and fatigue.
Glandular fever is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which is spread through saliva, kissing, sharing utensils, and exposure to coughs and sneezes.
Treatment for glandular fever involves drinking plenty of fluids, taking painkillers, getting plenty of rest, and avoiding contact sports to prevent complications.
Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted infection caused by bacteria.

Symptoms of gonorrhoea may include green or yellow fluid coming out of the penis, pain or a burning sensation when peeing, discomfort and swelling of the testicles, increased discharge from the vagina, pain in the lower tummy, and bleeding in between periods or after sex.
