Testing for gonorrhoea involves sending a sample from the infected area to a lab for analysis, which can be done using a swab or a urine sample.
Antibiotics are used to treat gonorrhoea, but some strains are becoming resistant to antibiotics, so retesting may be necessary.
Gout is a type of arthritis that causes sudden attacks of severe pain and swelling in the joints, especially in the toes, ankles, knees, and fingers.
It is estimated that between one and two in every 100 people in the UK are affected by gout, with the condition being more common in men over 30 and women after menopause.
Gout can be extremely painful and debilitating, but treatments are available to relieve symptoms and prevent further attacks.

Treatment for gout includes pain relief during an attack using medications like non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, or corticosteroids, as well as lifestyle changes and medication to lower uric acid levels in the body.
Gum disease is a very common condition where the gums become swollen, sore or infected.
If you have gum disease, your gums may bleed when you brush your teeth and you may have bad breath. This early stage of gum disease is known as gingivitis.
If gingivitis isn't treated, a condition called periodontitis can develop. This affects more tissues that support teeth and hold them in place.

In some cases, a condition called acute necrotising ulcerative gingivitis (ANUG) can develop suddenly. The symptoms of ANUG are usually more severe than those of gum disease and can include bleeding, painful gums, painful ulcers, receding gums between your teeth, bad breath, a metallic taste in your mouth, excess saliva in your mouth, difficulty swallowing or talking, and a high temperature (fever).
Haemorrhoids, also known as piles, are swellings containing enlarged blood vessels that are found inside or around the bottom (the rectum and anus).
Symptoms of haemorrhoids may include bleeding after passing a stool, itching, a lump hanging down outside of the anus, and soreness, redness, and swelling around the anus.
Haemorrhoids can be caused by increased pressure in the blood vessels in and around the anus, often due to straining on the toilet or chronic constipation.
Treatment for haemorrhoids may include dietary changes, medication, non-surgical procedures such as banding or injections, or surgery.
Hand, foot and mouth disease is a common infection that causes mouth ulcers and spots on the hands and feet.
Symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease include a high temperature, loss of appetite, coughing, abdominal pain, and a sore throat and mouth.
Mouth ulcers develop after 1 or 2 days, followed by a spotty rash and blisters on the hands, feet, and occasionally on the buttocks and groin.
Treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease involves staying at home, drinking plenty of fluids, eating soft foods, taking over-the-counter painkillers, and practicing good hygiene.
The main symptoms of hay fever include frequent sneezing, runny or blocked nose, itchy, red or watery eyes, and an itchy throat, mouth, nose, and ears.
Less commonly, hay fever may cause loss of sense of smell, facial pain, headaches, earache, and tiredness and fatigue.
Treatment options for hay fever include antihistamines to prevent allergic reactions and corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and swelling.

If hay fever symptoms worsen, do not improve with over-the-counter medication, or are accompanied by persistent complications such as worsening asthma or repeated sinusitis episodes, professional advice should be sought.
Head and neck cancer can develop in more than 30 areas within the head and neck, including the mouth, voice box, throat, salivary glands, nose, and sinuses.
Mouth cancer is the most common type of head and neck cancer and can affect the lips, tongue, cheeks, floor or roof of the mouth, and gums.
Laryngeal cancer develops in the tissue of the voice box and can cause symptoms such as hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, noisy breathing, and a persistent cough.
Throat cancers can affect the oropharynx, hypopharynx, and nasopharynx, and common symptoms include a lump in the neck, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing.
Head lice are tiny insects that live in hair and nits are the empty egg cases attached to hair that head lice hatch from.
Head lice are a common problem, particularly in school children aged 4 to 11.
They can live in the hair for a long time if not treated and can be irritating and frustrating to deal with.
Signs of head lice include small white eggs or nits in the hair, an itchy scalp, a rash on the back of the neck, and feeling as though something is moving in the hair.
Tension headaches are the most common type of headache and are characterized by a constant ache that affects both sides of the head.

Migraines are less common than tension headaches and are usually felt as a severe, throbbing pain at the front or side of the head, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and increased sensitivity to light or sound.

Cluster headaches are a rare type of headache that occur in clusters for a month or two at a time around the same time of year, causing intense pain around one eye and often accompanied by a watering or red eye and a blocked or runny nose.

Medication and painkiller headaches can occur as a side effect of taking certain medications or from taking too many painkillers, and can be relieved by stopping the medication or reducing painkiller use.
Hearing loss is a common problem that often develops with age or is caused by repeated exposure to loud noises.
The Royal National Institute for Deaf People (RNID) estimates that there are more than 10 million people in the UK with some degree of hearing impairment or deafness.
Early signs of hearing loss can include difficulty hearing other people clearly, asking people to repeat themselves, and listening to music or watching television with the volume higher than others.
Treatment options for hearing loss include digital hearing aids, bone anchored implants, middle ear implants, cochlear implants, and lip reading or sign language.
A heart attack occurs when there is a reduction in blood supply to part of the heart muscle, causing damage to the heart.

Tests to diagnose a heart attack may include an electrocardiogram (ECG), blood tests to check troponin levels, assessment of blood pressure and oxygen levels, a chest X-ray, an echocardiogram, and a coronary angiogram.
Treatment for a heart attack may include anti-emetics, antiplatelet therapy, coronary angioplasty, oxygen therapy, pain-relieving drugs, reperfusion treatment, and thrombolysis.
Complications of a heart attack can include arrhythmias and heart failure, which may require medication for management.
Symptoms of heart failure include breathlessness, a persistent cough, tiredness or fatigue, and swelling in the legs or ankles.
Causes of heart failure can include a heart attack, coronary heart disease, high blood pressure, viral infection, and congenital heart disease.
Tests to diagnose heart failure may include blood tests, a chest X-ray, an electrocardiogram (ECG), and an echocardiogram.
Treatment options for heart failure include medications such as ACE inhibitors, ARNI, beta blockers, diuretics, and MRAs, as well as the possibility of a heart transplant for severe cases.
Hepatitis A is a liver infection that is spread through contact with infected feces.

Symptoms of hepatitis A include fatigue, joint and muscle pain, fever, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, headache, rash, jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, and swollen and tender abdomen.
There is no cure for hepatitis A, but symptoms usually improve within a couple of months and most people develop lifelong immunity.

Vaccination is recommended for individuals at increased risk, such as close contacts of infected individuals, travelers to high-risk areas, individuals with chronic liver disease, men who have sex with men, and people who inject drugs.
Hepatitis B is a liver infection that is spread through blood and body fluids.
Symptoms of hepatitis B include tiredness, fever, aches and pains, loss of appetite, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and jaundice.
Treatment for hepatitis B depends on the duration of the infection, ranging from emergency treatment to relieve symptoms to long-term medication to control the virus and reduce liver damage.

Hepatitis B can be prevented through vaccination, especially for high-risk individuals such as newborns of infected mothers, close contacts of infected individuals, and people traveling to high-risk areas.
Hepatitis C is a liver infection that is spread through blood.
Symptoms of acute hepatitis C may include a high temperature, tiredness, loss of appetite, abdominal pain, feeling and being sick, and yellowing of the skin and eyes.

Symptoms of chronic hepatitis C can include feeling tired all the time, joint and muscle aches and pain, feeling sick, brain fog, mood swings, depression or anxiety, indigestion or bloating, itchy skin, and abdominal pain.
Treatment for hepatitis C takes 8 to 12 weeks and usually cures the infection, but steps should be taken to reduce the risk of reinfection.
A hiatus hernia is when part of the stomach squeezes up into the chest through an opening in the diaphragm.
Hiatus hernia can cause gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD), which is when stomach acid leaks into the oesophagus, causing symptoms such as heartburn and swallowing problems.
Hiatus hernia can be caused by a weak diaphragm or pressure on the abdomen, and it is more common in people over 50, overweight, or pregnant.

Treatment for hiatus hernia may include lifestyle changes (eating smaller meals, avoiding lying down after eating), medication (antacids, alginates, H2-receptor antagonists, proton-pump inhibitors), or surgery (laparoscopic nissen fundoplication for sliding hiatus hernias, surgery to reduce the risk of complications for para-oesophageal hiatus hernias).
High cholesterol is a condition where there is an excessive level of lipids in the blood, which can increase the risk of serious health conditions.

Cholesterol is carried in the blood by proteins called lipoproteins, with high-density lipoprotein (HDL) being considered "good cholesterol" and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) being considered "bad cholesterol".
High cholesterol can increase the risk of narrowing of the arteries, heart attack, stroke, transient ischaemic attack (TIA), and peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
Factors that can contribute to high cholesterol include an unhealthy diet, smoking, diabetes, high blood pressure, and a family history of stroke or heart disease.
HIV is a long-term health condition that weakens the immune system and can lead to serious illnesses if left untreated.
Symptoms of HIV can include fever, sore throat, body rash, tiredness, joint and muscle pain, swollen glands, and weight loss.
Testing for HIV can be done through blood tests, point of care tests, home sampling kits, or home testing kits.
Treatment for HIV involves taking antiretroviral medicines daily to suppress the virus and prevent further damage to the immune system.
Hodgkin lymphoma is a cancer that affects the lymphatic system, which is part of the immune system.
The main symptom of Hodgkin lymphoma is a painless swelling in a lymph node, usually in the neck, armpit, or groin.
Risk factors for Hodgkin lymphoma include having a weakened immune system, exposure to the Epstein-Barr virus, and a family history of the condition.
Treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma may involve chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or a combination of both.
Hodgkin lymphoma is a type of blood cancer that affects the lymphatic system.
The exact cause of Hodgkin lymphoma is unknown, but infections and poor immunity may play a role in its development.
The main symptom of Hodgkin lymphoma is painless swelling of lymph glands, typically in the neck or above the collarbone.
Treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma usually involves chemotherapy and sometimes radiotherapy, with possible side effects including nausea, hair loss, and low blood count.
Treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma has a high success rate and most people are cured.
Hodgkin lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphatic system, which helps protect against infection.
Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by abnormal growth of lymphocytes, which can form lumps in different parts of the body.

Common symptoms of Hodgkin lymphoma include painless lumps in the neck, armpit, or groin, fatigue, itching of the skin, and B symptoms such as high temperatures, heavy sweats, and unexplained weight loss.
Huntington's disease is a condition that damages nerve cells in the brain, causing them to stop working properly.
Symptoms of Huntington's disease can include behavioral changes, difficulty concentrating, uncontrollable movements, difficulty eating, and balance problems.
Huntington's disease is caused by a faulty gene that is inherited from a person's parents.
There is no cure for Huntington's disease, but medication and therapies can help manage the symptoms.
Hyperglycaemia (high blood sugar) can affect people with type 1 diabetes, type 2 diabetes, and pregnant women with gestational diabetes.
Hyperglycaemia can occasionally affect people who don't have diabetes, but usually only those who are seriously ill.
Hyperglycaemia shouldn't be confused with hypoglycaemia, which is when a person's blood sugar level drops too low.
Very high blood sugar levels can cause life-threatening complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and hyperosmolar hyperglycaemic state (HHS).
Hyperhidrosis is a common condition characterized by excessive sweating, which can affect the whole body or specific areas such as the armpits, palms, soles of the feet, face, and chest.
The sweating in hyperhidrosis does not pose a serious threat to health but can be embarrassing and distressing, leading to feelings of depression and anxiety.

Primary hyperhidrosis, which has no obvious cause, is thought to be the result of a problem with the nervous system that controls sweating. Secondary hyperhidrosis, which has an identifiable cause, can be triggered by factors such as pregnancy, menopause, anxiety, certain medications, and infections.

Treatment options for hyperhidrosis include lifestyle changes, such as wearing loose and light clothes and avoiding triggers that worsen sweating, as well as using powerful antiperspirants, undergoing iontophoresis or botulinum toxin injections, and in severe cases, considering surgery.
Hypoglycaemia is an abnormally low level of glucose in the blood, usually below four millimoles per litre.
Symptoms of hypoglycaemia include feeling hungry, sweating, dizziness, tiredness, blurred vision, trembling, and confusion.
Treatment for hypoglycaemia involves consuming sugary food or drink to raise blood glucose levels, followed by longer-acting carbohydrate foods.
Hypoglycaemia can be prevented by regularly monitoring blood glucose levels, sticking to medication plans, and eating regular meals.
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a condition in which the lungs become scarred and breathing becomes increasingly difficult.
Symptoms of IPF include shortness of breath, a persistent dry cough, tiredness, loss of appetite and weight loss, and rounded and swollen fingertips (clubbed fingers).
IPF can lead to secondary conditions such as chest infections, pulmonary hypertension, and heart failure.
Treatment for IPF includes self-care measures, medication to slow down the progression of scarring, oxygen support, pulmonary rehabilitation, and in some cases, a lung transplant.

Non-bullous impetigo is characterized by the appearance of red sores that quickly burst and leave behind thick, golden crusts. The crusts dry and leave a red mark that usually fades without scarring. Other symptoms, such as a high temperature and swollen glands, are rare but can occur in severe cases.

Bullous impetigo is characterized by the appearance of fluid-filled blisters that usually occur on the trunk or on the arms and legs. The blisters may quickly spread and burst, leaving a yellow crust that usually heals without scarring. Symptoms of fever and swollen glands are more common in bullous impetigo.

Impetigo is caused by the skin becoming infected with bacteria, usually Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. The bacteria can infect the skin through a break in otherwise healthy skin or through skin damaged by another underlying skin condition.

Treatment for impetigo usually involves the use of antibiotic creams or tablets. Antibiotic creams are recommended for mild cases that cover a small area, while antibiotic tablets may be prescribed for more severe or widespread infections.
Indigestion can cause pain or discomfort in the upper abdomen (dyspepsia) or burning pain behind the breastbone (heartburn).
Common symptoms of indigestion include feeling full or bloated, nausea, belching, and regurgitation of food or fluid.

Indigestion can be caused by stomach acid irritating the lining of the digestive system, increased sensitivity of the mucosa, or factors such as smoking, drinking, alcohol, pregnancy, stress, or certain medications.

Treatment for indigestion may involve making changes to diet and lifestyle, taking antacids or alginates for immediate relief, or using medications such as proton pump inhibitors or H2-receptor antagonists for persistent indigestion.
An ingrown toenail occurs when the sides of the toenail grow into the surrounding skin, often affecting the big toe.
Symptoms of an ingrown toenail include redness, swelling, tenderness, pain with pressure, inflammation, fluid build-up, overgrowth of skin, bleeding, and pus.
Causes of ingrown toenails include cutting toenails too short, wearing tight-fitting shoes, sweaty feet, injury, and the natural shape of the nail.

Treatment options for ingrown toenails include keeping feet clean, changing socks regularly, cutting toenails straight across, pushing the skin away from the nail, wearing comfortable shoes, and surgical procedures such as partial or total nail avulsion.
An inherited heart disease is one which has been passed on through your parents' genes.
Inherited cardiac conditions (ICC) is an umbrella term covering a wide variety of relatively rare diseases of the heart. They are also referred to as genetic cardiac conditions.
ICCs are caused by a fault ' also known as a mutation ' in one or more of our genes. If someone has a faulty gene, there's a 50/50 chance it can be passed on to your children.
Around 500 young people die every year in the UK as a result of a genetic heart disorder.
Insomnia is difficulty getting to sleep or staying asleep for long enough to feel refreshed the next morning.
Common symptoms of insomnia include difficulty falling asleep, waking up multiple times during the night, and feeling tired and irritable during the day.
Insomnia can be caused by factors such as stress and anxiety, poor sleeping environment, lifestyle factors, mental health conditions, physical health conditions, and certain medications.
Treatment options for insomnia include establishing good sleeping habits, cognitive and behavioral therapy, and in some cases, prescription sleeping tablets.
Iron deficiency anaemia is a condition where a lack of iron in the body leads to a reduction in the number of red blood cells.
Symptoms of iron deficiency anaemia include tiredness and lack of energy, shortness of breath, noticeable heartbeats, and a pale complexion.
The most common causes of iron deficiency anaemia are monthly periods in women, pregnancy, and gastrointestinal blood loss.
Treatment for iron deficiency anaemia involves taking iron supplements to boost iron levels in the body, as well as treating the underlying cause.
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common, long-term condition of the digestive system.
IBS does not pose a serious threat to your physical health and does not increase your chances of developing cancer or other bowel-related conditions.
The most common symptoms of IBS are abdominal pain and cramping, a change in bowel habits, bloating and swelling of the stomach, and excessive wind.
It is important to rule out other conditions such as coeliac disease and inflammatory bowel disease before diagnosing IBS.
Itching is a sensation that compels a person to scratch the affected area.
There are various causes of itching, including allergies, skin conditions, insect bites, and certain medications.
Treatment for itching may involve using over-the-counter creams or ointments, taking antihistamines, avoiding triggers, and practicing good skin hygiene.
In some cases, itching may require medical intervention, such as prescription medications or specialized treatments.
Itchy bottom is a strong urge to scratch the skin around your bottom (anus).
An itchy bottom that's worse at night can be caused by threadworms.

Sometimes an itchy bottom can be a symptom of another problem or condition, such as skin conditions like eczema or psoriasis, haemorrhoids (piles), bowel incontinence or diarrhoea, sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like genital warts, or ringworm.
To ease an itchy bottom, you can use soft toilet tissue, keep your bottom clean and dry, wear loose-fitting cotton underwear, and eat foods with fiber to help produce regular, solid poo.
Kaposi's sarcoma is a rare type of cancer caused by a virus and can affect the skin and internal organs.
The most common initial symptom of Kaposi's sarcoma is the appearance of small, painless, flat and discolored patches on the skin or inside the mouth.
Kaposi's sarcoma is caused by a virus called the human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), which is spread during sex, through saliva, or from a mother to her baby during birth.
There are 4 main types of Kaposi's sarcoma: HIV-related, classic, transplant-related, and endemic African, each with different treatment approaches.
Kidney cancer is the eighth most common cancer in adults in the UK.
Signs and symptoms of kidney cancer can include blood in your urine, a constant pain in your side, and a lump or swelling in the kidney area.
Kidney cancer most frequently affects people over 50 years of age and is more common among men.
Treatment for kidney cancer may involve surgery to remove the kidney, radiotherapy, targeted therapies, or immunotherapy.
A kidney infection (pyelonephritis) is a painful and unpleasant illness caused by bacteria traveling from the bladder into one or both of the kidneys.
Symptoms of a kidney infection often come on within a few hours and can include fever, chills, abdominal pain, and loss of appetite.
Most kidney infections can be treated at home with a course of antibiotics and painkillers, but severe cases may require hospitalization.
Complications of a kidney infection can include kidney abscess, blood poisoning, severe infection, kidney failure, and other problems such as high blood pressure or premature labor.
Kidney stones can develop in one or both kidneys and most often affect people aged 30 to 60.
They're quite common, with around 3 in 20 men and up to 2 in 20 women developing them at some stage of their lives.
The medical term for kidney stones is nephrolithiasis, and if they cause severe pain it's known as renal colic.

Small kidney stones may go undetected and be passed out painlessly in the urine. But it's fairly common for a stone to block part of the urinary system, such as the ureter or urethra, causing severe pain and sometimes a urinary tract infection.
Labyrinthitis is an inner ear infection that causes inflammation of the labyrinth, affecting hearing and balance.
Symptoms of labyrinthitis include vertigo, hearing loss, pressure in the ear, ringing in the ears, nausea, and headaches.
Labyrinthitis can be caused by viral or bacterial infections, with viral infections being more common.
Treatment for labyrinthitis may include medication to manage symptoms, such as dizziness and nausea, and vestibular rehabilitation therapy for chronic cases.
Lactose intolerance is a common digestive problem where the body is unable to digest lactose, a type of sugar mainly found in milk and dairy products.

Symptoms of lactose intolerance usually develop within a few hours of consuming food or drink that contains lactose and may include flatulence (wind), diarrhea, bloated stomach, and stomach cramps and pains.

Lactose intolerance can be diagnosed by removing lactose from the diet for two weeks to see if symptoms improve, and further testing such as hydrogen breath test or lactose tolerance test may be done.

Treatment for lactose intolerance involves making changes to the diet, such as avoiding or limiting sources of lactose, using lactase substitutes, and taking calcium and vitamin D supplements if necessary.
Laryngeal cancer is a type of cancer that affects the larynx (voice box).
The main symptoms of laryngeal cancer include a change in voice, difficulty swallowing, a lump or swelling in the neck, and a persistent cough.

Risk factors for laryngeal cancer include smoking tobacco, drinking large amounts of alcohol, having a family history of head and neck cancer, having an unhealthy diet, and exposure to certain chemicals and substances.
Treatment for laryngeal cancer may involve radiotherapy, surgery, chemotherapy, or a combination of these treatments.
Laryngitis is inflammation of the larynx (voice box) and typically improves without treatment within a week.
Common symptoms of laryngitis include hoarseness, difficulty speaking, sore throat, mild fever, irritating cough, and a constant need to clear your throat.
In some cases, laryngitis can cause breathing difficulties, especially in young children with smaller windpipes.

Laryngitis is often associated with other illnesses such as cold, flu, throat infection, or tonsillitis, and may be accompanied by symptoms like headache, swollen glands, runny nose, pain when swallowing, and fatigue.
Leg cramps are episodes of sudden pain in the muscles of the leg, usually in the calf muscles, that can last from a few seconds up to 10 minutes.
Leg cramps may be a sign of a more serious health condition if they last longer than 10 minutes, don't get better with movement, or are accompanied by numbness or swelling in the legs.

The cause of leg cramps can be unknown (idiopathic) or can be secondary to an underlying condition such as pregnancy, exercise, neurological conditions, liver disease, infection, toxins, or dehydration.
Treatment for leg cramps usually involves exercising the affected muscles, stretching the calf muscles, and addressing the underlying cause if necessary.
Lichen planus is a non-infectious, itchy rash that can affect many areas of the body, including the arms, legs, trunk, mouth, nails, scalp, and genital areas.
It is more common in adults over the age of 40 and affects men and women equally, although oral lichen planus is more common in women.
There is no cure for lichen planus, but treatments are available to manage the symptoms, such as steroid creams or ointments to relieve itchiness and control the rash.

In some cases, lichen planus can develop into erosive lichen planus, which causes painful ulcers and may increase the risk of certain types of cancer. Regular monitoring and early detection are important.
Primary liver cancer is a serious type of cancer that begins in the liver and is separate from secondary liver cancer.

Symptoms of liver cancer include unexplained weight loss, loss of appetite, feeling very full after eating, feeling sick and vomiting, pain or swelling in the abdomen, jaundice, itchy skin, and feeling very tired and weak.
The exact cause of liver cancer is unknown, but it is often associated with cirrhosis, which can be caused by excessive alcohol intake, hepatitis B or C infections, obesity, and an unhealthy diet.

Treatment for liver cancer depends on the stage of the condition and can include surgical resection, liver transplant, microwave or radiofrequency ablation, chemotherapy, alcohol injections, and sorafenib medication.
Alcohol-related liver disease is caused by years of alcohol misuse and can lead to cirrhosis.
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is a build-up of fat within liver cells, often seen in overweight or obese individuals.
Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver caused by a viral infection or exposure to harmful substances like alcohol.
Haemochromatosis is an inherited disorder that results in a gradual build-up of iron in the body, particularly around the liver.
Liver tumours can be non-cancerous (benign) or cancerous (malignant).
The two main types of primary liver cancer are hepatoblastoma, which occurs in children under 5 years old, and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which usually occurs in older children.
The liver is the largest organ in the body and has many functions, including producing proteins, breaking down waste products, and storing substances like glucose and vitamins.
The cause of most primary liver tumours in the western world is unknown, but in some parts of the world, HCC is commonly related to liver infection, especially in children with hepatitis B.
Loss of libido is a common problem affecting up to 1 in 5 men and even more women at some point in their life.
Relationship problems, stress, anxiety, and exhaustion can contribute to a loss of libido.
Depression and certain medications, such as antidepressants and medications for high blood pressure or depression, can also reduce sex drive.
Long-term medical conditions, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and obesity, can have a negative effect on libido.
Lung cancer is one of the most common and serious types of cancer.
Symptoms of lung cancer may include a persistent cough, coughing up blood, breathlessness, unexplained tiredness and weight loss, and an ache or pain when breathing or coughing.
There are two main types of primary lung cancer: non-small-cell lung cancer and small-cell lung cancer.
Treatment for lung cancer may include surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and biological therapies.
Lupus is a complex condition that affects many parts of the body and causes symptoms ranging from mild to life-threatening.
The main symptoms of lupus are fatigue, joint pain, and rashes.
Lupus is an autoimmune condition caused by problems with the immune system attacking healthy cells, tissue, and organs.
Treatment for lupus involves a combination of self-care measures and medication, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, hydroxychloroquine, corticosteroids, and immunosuppressants.
Lyme disease is a bacterial infection spread to humans by infected ticks.
Many people with Lyme disease develop a circular rash around the tick bite.
Other symptoms of Lyme disease include fatigue, muscle and joint pain, headaches, and fever.
If left untreated, Lyme disease can lead to more serious symptoms such as joint swelling, nerve problems, and heart problems.
Lymphoedema is a chronic condition that causes swelling in the body's tissues, usually in the arms or legs.
Symptoms of lymphoedema include swelling in all or part of a limb, an aching or heavy feeling, difficulty with movement, repeated skin infections, and the skin becoming hard and tight.
Lymphoedema can be caused by a problem with the lymphatic system, such as abnormal development, damage, or an increase in fluid in the tissues.
Treatment for lymphoedema includes compression bandages and garments, skin care, movement and exercises, and specialised massage techniques.
Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by a strain of chlamydia bacteria.
Symptoms of LGV may include swollen lymph glands in the groin and ulcers or sores on the penis, vagina, or around the anus.
Testing for LGV involves booking an appointment at a sexual health service or contacting a GP practice for an appointment.
LGV can be treated with antibiotics, and it is important to avoid having sex until both you and your partner have finished treatment to prevent transmission.
Malaria is a serious tropical disease spread by mosquitoes and can be fatal if not diagnosed and treated quickly.
Symptoms of malaria include high temperature (fever), headache, sweats, chills, muscle aches or pains, vomiting, and diarrhea.
Malaria is caused by the Plasmodium parasite and is spread to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes.
Malaria can be prevented by being aware of the risks, taking precautions to prevent mosquito bites, and taking antimalarial tablets.
A malignant brain tumour is a fast-growing cancer that spreads to other areas of the brain and spine.
Common symptoms of a malignant brain tumour include severe headaches, seizures, persistent nausea and vomiting, mental or behavioural changes, and weakness or paralysis on one side of the body.
Most malignant brain tumours develop from glial tissue, such as astrocytomas, oligodendrogliomas, and ependymomas.
Treatment for malignant brain tumours may involve surgery to remove the tumour, followed by radiotherapy and/or chemotherapy to kill any remaining cancerous cells.
Malnutrition is caused by not eating enough or not eating enough of the right food to provide the necessary nutrients.
Symptoms of malnutrition include unplanned weight loss, muscle loss, low body mass index (BMI), and vitamin and mineral deficiencies.
Medical conditions such as cancer, liver disease, COPD, mental health conditions, and digestive disorders can contribute to malnutrition.
Treatment for malnutrition may involve making dietary changes, increasing calorie and protein intake, and using oral nutritional supplements or tube feeding if necessary.
Measles is an infection that spreads easily and can have serious complications.
Symptoms of measles include cold-like symptoms, red and swollen eyes, high fever, loss of appetite, and tiredness.
The measles rash appears a few days after the initial symptoms and is made up of small red-brown spots that spread across the body.
Measles can lead to complications such as pneumonia and encephalitis, but usually resolves within 7 to 10 days.
Meningitis is an infection of the protective membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord.
Symptoms of meningitis can include a high temperature, headache, stiff neck, and a blotchy rash that doesn't fade when a glass is rolled over it.
Meningitis can be spread through sneezing, coughing, kissing, and sharing utensils.
Vaccinations are available to offer protection against certain causes of meningitis.
Mesothelioma is a type of cancer that develops in the lining of organs and is usually linked to asbestos exposure.
Symptoms of mesothelioma in the lining of the lungs include chest pain, shortness of breath, fatigue, persistent cough, and loss of appetite.
Mesothelioma is almost always caused by exposure to asbestos, which can damage the lungs over time.
Treatment for mesothelioma focuses on controlling symptoms and may include chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and surgery.
Otitis media is an infection of the middle ear that causes inflammation and fluid build-up behind the eardrum.
Symptoms of a middle ear infection include earache, high temperature, vomiting, lack of energy, and slight hearing loss.
Young children and babies with an ear infection may also rub or pull their ear, have difficulty hearing, be irritable, lose their balance, or have a decreased appetite.
Most ear infections get better on their own within 3 to 5 days and do not require specific treatment, but if symptoms persist or worsen, medical advice should be sought.
Migraine is a common health condition that affects around 1 in every 5 women and around 1 in every 15 men, usually beginning in early adulthood.

The main symptom of a migraine is usually an intense headache on one side of the head, which can also affect the face or neck. Other symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, increased sensitivity to light and sound, sweating, poor concentration, and abdominal pain.
Migraines can be categorized into different types, including migraine with aura, migraine without aura, and migraine aura without headache.

Migraines can be triggered by various factors, such as hormonal changes, physical triggers like tiredness or poor posture, dietary triggers like missed meals or certain foods, environmental triggers like bright lights or loud noises, and certain medications.
A miscarriage is the loss of your baby before 24 weeks, with early miscarriages happening in the first 12 weeks and late miscarriages happening between 12 and 24 weeks.
Most miscarriages occur without a clear reason and are unlikely to be caused by anything the mother did or didn't do.
About 1 out of 5 pregnancies end in a miscarriage, although the actual number may be higher due to unrecorded cases.
Medical help should be sought if there is vaginal bleeding, strong cramping pain, water breaking, or a change in the baby's movements.
Motor neurone disease (MND) is a rare condition that progressively damages parts of the nervous system, leading to muscle weakness and wasting.
MND can affect various muscle activities, including gripping, walking, speaking, swallowing, and breathing.
The symptoms of MND start gradually and tend to appear on one side of the body first, getting progressively worse over time.
Treatment for MND focuses on relieving symptoms and may include medication, physiotherapy, speech and language therapy, and breathing support.
Mouth cancer, also known as oral cancer, is a tumour that develops on the surface of the tongue, mouth, lips, or gums.
Symptoms of mouth cancer include red or white patches in the mouth or throat, ulcers, and a lump.
Risk factors for developing mouth cancer include smoking or using tobacco products, drinking alcohol, and infection with the human papilloma virus (HPV).
Treatment options for mouth cancer include surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and photodynamic therapy (PDT).
Mouth ulcers are round or oval sores that commonly appear inside the mouth on the cheeks, lips, and tongue. They can be white, red, yellow, or grey in color and swollen.
Most mouth ulcers clear up by themselves within 1 to 2 weeks without treatment. However, treatment can help reduce swelling and ease discomfort.
Possible causes of mouth ulcers include accidentally biting the inside of the cheek or a sharp tooth, poorly fitting dentures, hard food, and a faulty filling.
Mouth ulcers can also be caused by certain medical conditions such as viral infections, vitamin B12 or iron deficiency, Crohn's disease, and weakened immune system.
Multiple myeloma is a type of bone marrow cancer that affects the plasma cells inside the bone marrow.
Common symptoms of multiple myeloma include bone pain, weak bones that break easily, tiredness and shortness of breath, repeated infections, and unusual bleeding.
Risk factors for multiple myeloma include having monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance (MGUS), being male, being over the age of 60, and being of black ethnicity.
Treatment for multiple myeloma may involve a combination of anti-myeloma medications, medications to prevent and treat complications, and participation in clinical trials.
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a condition that affects the brain and/or spinal cord, causing symptoms like problems with vision, arm or leg movement, sensation, or balance.
MS is a lifelong condition that can sometimes cause serious disability, but symptoms can be treated and managed.
There are more than 130,000 people diagnosed with MS in the UK, and it is often diagnosed in people in their 20s and 30s, although it can develop at any age and is more common in women than men.

Common symptoms of MS include muscle spasms, stiffness, and weakness; vision problems; abnormal sensations; mobility problems; pain; bladder and bowel problems; sexual problems; speech and swallowing difficulties; fatigue; mental health issues; and problems with thinking, learning, and planning.
Mumps is an infection that causes painful swellings at the side of the face under the ears, giving a distinctive 'hamster face' appearance.
Other symptoms of mumps can include headaches, joint pain, feeling sick, dry mouth, mild stomach pain, feeling tired, loss of appetite, and a high temperature.
Mumps is spread through tiny droplets that come out of the nose and mouth when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
Mumps can be prevented by receiving the MMR vaccine, which is given in 2 doses as part of the NHS childhood vaccination programme.
The main symptoms of M'ni're's disease include vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and a feeling of pressure or fullness in the ear.
M'ni're's disease most commonly affects people aged 20 to 60, with a slightly higher prevalence in women.
Treatment for M'ni're's disease focuses on managing symptoms and may include medications, dietary changes, tinnitus treatment, balance training, relaxation techniques, and surgery in severe cases.

The exact cause of M'ni're's disease is unknown, but it is believed to be related to a problem with pressure in the inner ear and can be influenced by factors such as family history and fluid imbalances.
Pyridostigmine is a medication used to treat myasthenia gravis by temporarily improving nerve to muscle transmission and reducing muscle weakness.
Steroid tablets, such as prednisolone, may be prescribed if pyridostigmine is not effective. They work by reducing immune system activity and are usually taken every other day.

Immunosuppressants, such as azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, and methotrexate, may be recommended if steroids do not control symptoms or if a high dose of steroids is needed. These medications reduce immune system activity and are taken daily.

Side effects of pyridostigmine, steroids, and immunosuppressants may include stomach upset, diarrhea, drooling, weight gain, infection, and increased risk of infections. Regular blood tests are often required to monitor the effects of immunosuppressants.
Nasal and sinus cancer primarily affects the nasal cavity and sinuses.
Common symptoms of nasal and sinus cancer include a persistent blocked nose, nosebleeds, mucus drainage from the nose (which may be blood-stained), and a decreased sense of smell.

At a later stage, symptoms may include pain or numbness in the face, swollen glands in the neck, partial loss of vision or double vision, a bulging or persistently watering eye, and a lump or growth on the face, nose, or roof of the mouth.
Risk factors for nasal and sinus cancer include being male, prolonged exposure to certain substances at work, smoking, and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.
Nasopharyngeal cancer is a rare type of cancer that affects the part of the throat connecting the back of the nose to the back of the mouth.
Symptoms of nasopharyngeal cancer can include a lump in the neck, hearing loss, tinnitus, a blocked or stuffy nose, and nosebleeds.
The exact cause of nasopharyngeal cancer is unknown, but factors such as ethnicity, diet, exposure to certain viruses, and family history can increase the risk.
The main treatments for nasopharyngeal cancer are radiotherapy and chemotherapy, often used in combination. Surgery is not commonly used.
Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor in children outside of the brain and accounts for 8% of all childhood cancers.

Symptoms of neuroblastoma vary depending on the location of the tumor and may include abdominal swelling, constipation or difficulty passing urine, breathlessness, difficulty swallowing, visible lumps in the neck, weakness in the legs, high blood pressure, and general discomfort.
Diagnosis of neuroblastoma involves various tests such as biopsy, blood and bone marrow tests, X-rays, CT or MRI scans, and an MIBG scan to determine the extent of the disease.

Treatment options for neuroblastoma include surgery, chemotherapy, high-dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue, monoclonal antibody treatment, and radiotherapy, depending on the stage and spread of the tumor.
Neuroendocrine tumours (NETs) are rare tumours that can occur in the cells of the neuroendocrine system.
NETs can be malignant (cancerous) or benign (non-cancerous) and often grow slowly.
Gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumours (GEP NETs) develop in the gut or pancreas.
Symptoms of neuroendocrine tumours can vary depending on where it is and what hormones it produces.
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a range of conditions caused by a build-up of fat in the liver, commonly seen in overweight or obese individuals.
NAFLD can progress to serious liver damage, including cirrhosis, and is associated with an increased risk of diabetes, heart attacks, and strokes.
The main stages of NAFLD are simple fatty liver (steatosis), non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), fibrosis, and cirrhosis.
Risk factors for NAFLD include obesity, type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, age over 50, and smoking.
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is an uncommon cancer that develops in the lymphatic system, which is a network of vessels and glands spread throughout your body.
The most common symptom of non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a painless swelling in a lymph node, usually in the neck, armpit or groin.
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma can occur at any age, but your chances of developing the condition increase as you get older, with most cases diagnosed in people over 65.
The exact cause of non-Hodgkin lymphoma is unknown, but certain factors can increase your risk, such as having a weakened immune system or being exposed to certain viruses.
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a type of blood cancer that is more common in boys than girls.
Treatment for NHL often involves chemotherapy, which is the use of anti-cancer drugs to destroy cancer cells.
Side effects of NHL treatment can include nausea, vomiting, hair loss, low blood count, tiredness, and diarrhea.
After treatment, some children may develop late side effects such as reduced bone growth, changes in organ function, and an increased risk of developing another cancer.
Norovirus causes diarrhoea and vomiting and is one of the most common stomach bugs in the UK.
Norovirus can be very unpleasant but usually clears up by itself in a few days.
You can normally look after yourself or your child at home.
Avoid going to your GP, as norovirus can spread to others very easily.
To stop a nosebleed, sit down, lean forward, and firmly pinch the soft part of your nose for at least 10 to 15 minutes.
Place an ice pack or bag of frozen vegetables covered by a towel on your forehead or back of your neck to help stop the bleeding.
Seek medical advice if you are taking blood-thinning medication, have a condition that affects blood clotting, experience symptoms of anemia, or have recurring nosebleeds.
Common causes of nosebleeds include picking your nose, blowing your nose forcefully, drinking alcohol, minor nose injuries, and changes in humidity or temperature.
Obesity is a condition characterized by being very overweight, with a lot of body fat.
It is estimated to affect around one in every four adults and one in every five children aged 10 to 11 in the UK.
Obesity is typically diagnosed using body mass index (BMI), which measures whether a person is a healthy weight for their height.
Obesity can lead to serious health conditions, including type 2 diabetes, coronary heart disease, some types of cancer, and stroke.
OCD is a mental health condition that causes obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors.
Symptoms of OCD include intrusive thoughts, intense anxiety, repetitive behaviors, and temporary relief.
Common obsessions in OCD include fear of harm, contamination, and a need for symmetry or orderliness.
Treatment for OCD may involve cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and medication, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).
Obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) is a condition where the walls of the throat relax and narrow during sleep, interrupting normal breathing.
Symptoms of OSA include loud snoring, noisy and laboured breathing, and repeated short periods where breathing is interrupted by gasping or snorting.
OSA can be diagnosed through observation at a sleep clinic or by using a testing device worn overnight at home.

Treatment options for OSA include lifestyle changes, such as losing weight and avoiding alcohol, using a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device, and wearing a mandibular advancement device (MAD).
Oesophageal cancer is a type of cancer affecting the oesophagus (gullet) and is more common in men than women.

Symptoms of oesophageal cancer can include difficulty swallowing, persistent indigestion or heartburn, bringing up food soon after eating, loss of appetite and weight loss, and pain or discomfort in the upper tummy, chest, or back.

Risk factors for oesophageal cancer include persistent gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD), smoking, drinking too much alcohol, being overweight or obese, and having an unhealthy diet low in fruit and vegetables.
Treatment for oesophageal cancer may involve surgery to remove the affected section of the oesophagus, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.
Oral thrush, also known as oral candidosis, is a fungal infection of the mouth caused by Candida yeasts.

Symptoms of oral thrush include white patches in the mouth that can be wiped off, loss of taste or unpleasant taste, redness inside the mouth and throat, cracks at the corners of the mouth, and a painful, burning sensation.
If left untreated, oral thrush can persist and make eating and drinking difficult, and in severe cases, it can spread further into the body.
Oral thrush can be diagnosed by a GP through a mouth examination and may require blood tests to check for underlying conditions.
Osteoporosis weakens bones, making them fragile and more likely to break, often only diagnosed after a minor fall or sudden impact causes a fracture.
The most common injuries in people with osteoporosis are wrist fractures, hip fractures, and fractures of the spinal bones.
Osteoporosis can cause a stooped posture and chronic pain, especially in the spine.

Risk factors for osteoporosis include age, sex (women are more at risk, especially after menopause), family history, certain medical conditions, and lifestyle factors such as low body mass index, heavy drinking, and smoking.
Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that commonly occurs in older children and teenagers, and is rarely seen in children under 5.
The main symptom of osteosarcoma is pain in the affected bone, which may initially come and go and then become more severe and constant, especially at night.
Diagnosis of osteosarcoma involves a physical examination, blood tests, imaging tests such as X-rays, MRI or CT scans, and a biopsy of the tumor.
Treatment for osteosarcoma may include chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, which may involve limb-sparing surgery or amputation depending on the extent of the tumor.
Otitis externa is an infection that causes inflammation of the ear canal, resulting in symptoms such as ear pain, itching, redness, and discharge.
It is commonly referred to as "swimmer's ear" because getting water in the ear can increase the likelihood of inflammation.
Otitis externa is often caused by bacterial infection, but can also be caused by irritation, fungal infections, or allergies.
Treatment for otitis externa may include ear drops, avoiding water in the affected ear, and using pain relief medication.
Ovarian cancer is most common in women and anyone with ovaries who has been through the menopause (usually over the age of 50).
Early symptoms of ovarian cancer include persistent bloating, pain in the pelvis and lower stomach, and difficulty eating.
Risk factors for ovarian cancer include age, family history of ovarian or breast cancer, and the number of eggs the ovaries release.
Treatment for ovarian cancer may involve surgery to remove the ovaries and fallopian tubes, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiotherapy.
Germ cell tumours of the ovary are the most common type of ovarian cancer in teenagers and young women.
Symptoms of germ cell tumours of the ovary may include pain or swelling in the abdomen, a feeling of fullness or bloating in the abdomen, needing to urinate more often, and irregular periods.
Tests for ovarian cancer may include a blood test, an ultrasound of the ovaries, and an internal examination to check the organs in the pelvis.

Treatment for germ cell tumours of the ovary may involve surgery to remove the affected ovary and fallopian tube, chemotherapy to get rid of any remaining cancer cells, and in some cases, radiotherapy.

Overactive thyroid, also known as hyperthyroidism, occurs when there is too much thyroid hormone in the body, leading to symptoms such as nervousness, hyperactivity, unexplained weight loss, and swelling of the thyroid gland.
The most common cause of an overactive thyroid is Graves' disease, an autoimmune condition where the immune system attacks the thyroid gland and causes it to produce excess hormones.

Treatment options for an overactive thyroid include thionamides, which stop the thyroid gland from producing too much hormone, radioiodine treatment to shrink the thyroid gland, and surgery to remove part or all of the thyroid gland.
Complications of an overactive thyroid can include Graves' ophthalmopathy, a condition affecting the eyes, and thyroid storm, a severe and life-threatening flare-up of symptoms.
Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare type of breast cancer that affects the skin of one nipple.
Symptoms of Paget's disease include an itchy, red rash on the nipple that can extend to the surrounding skin, as well as itchiness, burning, and bleeding from the nipple.
Paget's disease is usually a sign of breast cancer, either invasive or non-invasive.
Treatment for Paget's disease may involve surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or hormone therapy, depending on the type and stage of the cancer.
Pancreatic cancer is caused by the abnormal and uncontrolled growth of cells in the pancreas.
The main symptoms of pancreatic cancer include pain in the stomach or back, unexpected weight loss, and jaundice.
Risk factors for pancreatic cancer include age (50 to 80 years old), smoking, and having a history of certain health conditions such as diabetes and chronic pancreatitis.
Treatment for pancreatic cancer may involve surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.
Panic disorder is a condition characterized by recurring and regular panic attacks, often for no apparent reason.
Panic attacks can cause symptoms such as nausea, sweating, trembling, and a sensation of an irregular heartbeat.
The exact cause of panic disorder is not fully understood, but it is thought to be a combination of physical and psychological factors.
Treatment for panic disorder may involve psychological therapy, medication, and self-help techniques such as relaxation and exercise.
Parkinson's disease is a condition in which parts of the brain become progressively damaged over many years.
The three main symptoms of Parkinson's disease are involuntary shaking of particular parts of the body (tremor), slow movement, and stiff and inflexible muscles.

A person with Parkinson's disease can also experience a wide range of other physical and psychological symptoms, including depression and anxiety, balance problems, loss of sense of smell, problems sleeping, and memory problems.
Although there's currently no cure for Parkinson's disease, treatments are available to help reduce the main symptoms and maintain quality of life for as long as possible.
Patau's syndrome, also known as Trisomy 13, is a rare genetic condition that affects babies in the womb and causes health problems throughout their life.
Babies with Patau's syndrome have an extra copy of chromosome 13, which can be present in some or all of their cells and lead to various health conditions.
There are three forms of Patau's syndrome: full form, mosaic form, and partial form, each with different levels of chromosome involvement.
Babies with Patau's syndrome may experience a range of health issues, including heart problems, cleft lip/palate, brain development issues, seizures, hearing loss, joint contractures, and eye issues.
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a bacterial infection that affects the female reproductive system, including the womb, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.

Symptoms of PID can include pain around the pelvis or lower tummy, discomfort or pain during sex, pain when peeing, bleeding between periods or after sex, heavy or painful periods, and unusual vaginal discharge.
Testing for PID involves discussing symptoms, having an internal examination, and taking swabs from the vagina and cervix. Ultrasound scans may also be done.
Treatment for PID includes oral antibiotics for early-stage cases and hospitalization for more severe cases. It is important to take all antibiotics and finish the entire course of treatment.
Pelvic organ prolapse is when one or more of the pelvic organs (womb, bladder, or bowel) slip from their usual position, causing the vaginal wall to bulge into or out of the vagina.

Symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse may include a feeling of a bulge or something coming down or out of the vagina, discomfort during sex, problems with urination, and a slow stream or feeling of not emptying the bladder fully.
Diagnosis of pelvic organ prolapse involves a pelvic examination, which includes an internal examination of the vagina. Further tests may be needed depending on the doctor's assessment.

Treatment options for pelvic organ prolapse include lifestyle changes such as pelvic floor exercises and maintaining a healthy weight, the use of vaginal pessaries to support the vaginal walls, hormone replacement therapy to relieve symptoms, and surgery in severe cases.
Penile cancer is a rare type of cancer that occurs on the skin of the penis or within the penis.
The number of penile cancer cases has increased by more than 20% over the last 30 years, possibly due to changes in sexual practices.
Improvements in diagnosis, staging, and treatment have led to a reduction in the number of deaths resulting from penile cancer.

Symptoms of penile cancer include a growth or sore on the penis that doesn't heal within 4 weeks, bleeding from the penis or under the foreskin, foul-smelling discharge, thickening of the skin of the penis or foreskin, change in the color of the skin, and a rash on the penis.
Peripheral neuropathy is a condition where the nerves in the extremities, such as the hands and feet, are damaged.
The symptoms of peripheral neuropathy can vary depending on which nerves are affected and may include numbness, tingling, pain, and muscle weakness.
The most common cause of peripheral neuropathy is diabetes, but it can also be caused by other health conditions, physical injury, infections, and certain medications.
Treatment for peripheral neuropathy focuses on managing the underlying cause, relieving pain, and treating other symptoms such as muscle weakness or erectile dysfunction.
Personality disorders are conditions where an individual differs significantly from an average person in their thinking, perception, feeling, and ability to relate to others.

Common features of personality disorders include being overwhelmed by negative feelings, avoiding other people, feeling emotionally disconnected, displaying odd behavior, and having difficulty maintaining stable and close relationships.

There are different types of personality disorders, including paranoid personality disorder, schizoid personality disorder, schizotypal personality disorder, borderline personality disorder, histrionic personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, avoidant personality disorder, and obsessive-compulsive personality disorder.

Treatment for personality disorders usually involves psychological therapy tailored to the individual, which aims to improve their ability to regulate thoughts and emotions. Medication may also be prescribed to treat associated problems like depression, anxiety, and psychotic symptoms.
Pleurisy is inflammation of the sheet-like layers that cover the lungs (the pleura).
The most common symptom of pleurisy is a sharp chest pain when breathing deeply, sometimes felt in the shoulder.
Other symptoms can include shortness of breath and a dry cough.
Pleurisy can usually be diagnosed by studying your symptoms, and further tests may be needed to identify the underlying cause.
Pneumonia is inflammation of the tissue in one or both lungs, usually caused by a bacterial infection.
Symptoms of pneumonia include coughing with thick mucus, difficulty breathing, rapid heartbeat, fever, and loss of appetite.
Pneumonia can be caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi, or aspiration of foreign objects or harmful substances.
Mild pneumonia can be treated at home with rest, antibiotics, and fluids, while severe cases may require hospital treatment.
Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) causes pain, stiffness, and inflammation in the muscles around the shoulders, neck, and hips.
The main symptom of PMR is muscle stiffness in the morning lasting longer than 45 minutes, along with other symptoms such as fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, weight loss, and depression.
The cause of PMR is unknown, but it is more common in women over 50 years old.
Treatment for PMR involves taking a corticosteroid medication called prednisolone to relieve symptoms, with a long-term course of treatment lasting 18 months to two years.
Post-polio syndrome is a slow progressive condition that affects some people who have had polio, causing problems in daily activities.
Polio is a serious viral infection that can be prevented with vaccination and used to be common worldwide.

Symptoms of post-polio syndrome include muscle weakness, shrinking of the muscles, tight joints, pain in muscles or joints, chronic fatigue, swallowing and speech problems, respiratory problems, cramps and muscle twitching, and sensitivity to cold temperatures.
Treatment for post-polio syndrome involves exercise and rest, painkillers, mobility aids, treatment of breathing problems, healthy eating and weight control, and coping with psychological factors.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is an anxiety disorder caused by very stressful, frightening or distressing events.
Symptoms of PTSD include reliving the traumatic event through nightmares and flashbacks, feelings of isolation, irritability, and guilt, and problems with sleeping and concentration.
PTSD can be caused by various traumatic events such as serious road accidents, violent assaults, prolonged abuse or neglect, witnessing violent deaths, military combat, and natural disasters.

Treatment for PTSD may involve psychotherapy, such as trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR), and medication, such as antidepressants.
Postnatal depression is a type of depression that can affect parents after having a baby.
It is a common problem, affecting more than 1 in every 10 mothers within a year of giving birth.
With the right support, including self-help strategies and therapy, most people make a full recovery from postnatal depression.
Symptoms of postnatal depression can include persistent sadness, loss of interest, lack of energy, trouble sleeping, difficulty bonding with the baby, and thoughts of self-harm or suicide.
Pressure ulcers are injuries that break down the skin and underlying tissue, caused by sustained pressure on an area of skin.
They can range in severity from patches of discolored skin to open wounds that expose the bone or muscle.
People with mobility problems, health conditions that affect blood flow, and those over 70 years old are particularly vulnerable to pressure ulcers.
Treatment options include changing positions regularly, using special mattresses and cushions, and using dressings, creams, and ointments to relieve pressure and promote healing.
Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men and anyone with a prostate in the UK.
Symptoms of prostate cancer include needing to urinate more frequently, difficulty in starting to pee, weak flow, and feeling that your bladder has not emptied fully.
The causes of prostate cancer are largely unknown, but age, ethnicity, family history, obesity, exercise, and diet may increase the risk.
Treatment options for prostate cancer include watchful waiting, surgery, radiotherapy, hormone therapy, and chemotherapy.
Psoriasis is a skin condition that causes red, flaky, crusty patches of skin covered with silvery scales.
Psoriasis affects around 2% of people in the UK and can start at any age, but most often develops in adults under 35 years old.
The severity of psoriasis varies greatly from person to person, with some experiencing only minor irritation while others have a major impact on their quality of life.
Treatments for psoriasis include topical creams, phototherapy, and systemic medications, depending on the type and severity of the condition.
Psoriatic arthritis is a type of arthritis that develops in some people with the skin condition psoriasis, causing inflammation, stiffness, and pain in the joints.
The condition affects specific areas such as the hands, feet, knees, elbows, neck, and spine, and can also involve tendons.
Psoriatic arthritis can be diagnosed by a rheumatologist if a person has both psoriasis and joint problems, and other types of arthritis have been ruled out.

Treatment options for psoriatic arthritis include non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), steroid medication, disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs), biological treatments, and complementary therapies.
The two main symptoms of psychosis are hallucinations and delusions.
Psychosis can be caused by mental health conditions such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, as well as severe stress or anxiety.
Treatment for psychosis involves a combination of antipsychotic medication, psychological therapies, and social support.
Complications of psychosis can include self-harm, an increased risk of suicide, weight gain from antipsychotic medication, and the development of metabolic syndrome.
Pubic lice, also known as crabs, are tiny insects that live on coarse human body hair, such as pubic hair around the penis or vagina.
The most common symptom of pubic lice is itchy red spots, caused by an allergy to the lice saliva or poo.
Pubic lice are very small (2mm long) and grey-brown in color, and can be found in hair on the chest, armpits, face, and eyelashes.
Pubic lice are spread through close body contact, most commonly sexual contact, and can be treated with medicated creams or shampoos.

Rare cancers in children can be grouped into categories such as cancers that only affect children, cancers that usually affect adults, rare cancers in the head and neck area, rare hormonal/endocrine cancers, rare brain tumors, and rare skin cancers.
The causes of most rare childhood cancers are unknown, but a family history of certain types of cancer may suggest an inherited faulty gene.
Treatment for rare childhood cancers typically involves surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy, either individually or in combination.

Clinical trials for rare childhood cancers are not usually available, but organizations like the Children's Cancer and Leukaemia Group work to improve care and treatment and promote research in rare tumors.
Raynaud's phenomenon is a condition that affects the blood supply to certain parts of the body, usually the fingers and toes.
It is often triggered by cold temperatures, anxiety, or stress, causing the blood vessels to go into a temporary spasm and block the flow of blood.
Symptoms of Raynaud's include changes in color to white, blue, and red in the affected area, along with numbness, pain, and pins and needles.
Treatment for Raynaud's may involve self-help measures such as keeping warm, quitting smoking, and managing stress, or medication such as nifedipine to relieve symptoms.
Reactive arthritis, formerly known as Reiter's syndrome, causes inflammation in various parts of the body.
The most common areas affected by reactive arthritis are the joints, eyes, and urethra.
It is usually caused by an infection, such as a sexually transmitted infection or a bowel infection.
Treatment for reactive arthritis focuses on relieving symptoms and may include non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs).

Restless legs syndrome, also known as Willis-Ekbom disease, causes an overwhelming urge to move the legs and can also cause an unpleasant crawling or creeping sensation in the feet, calves, and thighs.
Restless legs syndrome is associated with involuntary jerking of the legs and arms, known as periodic limb movements in sleep (PLMS), and can disrupt a person's daily activities.
The exact cause of restless legs syndrome is often unknown, but it may be related to how the body handles dopamine, a chemical involved in controlling muscle movement.

Treatment for restless legs syndrome may include lifestyle changes such as adopting good sleep habits and exercising regularly, as well as medication to regulate dopamine levels and treat underlying health conditions.
Retinoblastoma is an uncommon eye cancer that usually affects children under 5, although it can affect children of any age.
Treatment for retinoblastoma depends on the number, position, and size of the tumors in the eye, and aims to get rid of the cancer while preserving sight.
Some treatments for retinoblastoma include cryotherapy, laser therapy, plaque therapy, thermotherapy, chemotherapy, surgery, and radiotherapy.

Follow-up care for retinoblastoma involves frequent eye examinations under anesthesia to check for recurrence or new tumors, and children with heritable retinoblastoma are at increased risk for other types of cancer later in life.
Rhabdomyosarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that primarily affects children under the age of 10, with a higher incidence in boys than girls.
Treatment for rhabdomyosarcoma may involve a combination of chemotherapy, surgery, and radiotherapy, depending on the size and location of the tumor.

Common symptoms of rhabdomyosarcoma include a lump or swelling in the affected area, obstruction and discharge from the nose or throat in head and neck tumors, pain or discomfort in the abdomen and constipation in abdominal tumors, and blood in the urine and difficulty urinating in bladder tumors.

Long-term side effects of treatment for rhabdomyosarcoma may include reduced bone growth, infertility, changes in heart and kidney function, and an increased risk of developing another cancer later in life.
Rheumatoid arthritis is a long-term condition that causes pain, swelling, and stiffness in the joints.
The main symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis affecting the joints are pain, stiffness, and swelling.
Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks the cells that line the joints, causing inflammation and damage.

Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis includes medications to control symptoms and slow down the progression of the condition, as well as supportive therapies like physiotherapy and occupational therapy.
Ringworm is a common fungal infection that causes a red or silvery ring-like rash on the skin.
Other fungal infections, such as athlete's foot and jock itch, can affect different parts of the body.
Fungal infections can be spread through direct skin contact, sharing objects, or contact with infected soil.
Treatment for fungal infections may include antifungal creams, tablets, or shampoos, and practicing good hygiene can help prevent the spread of infection.
Rosacea is a long-term skin condition that mainly affects the face and can have a significant psychological impact.
Symptoms of rosacea include flushing, burning and stinging sensations, permanent redness, spots, and visible blood vessels.
The exact cause of rosacea is unknown, but possible factors include abnormalities in blood vessels, skin peptides, microscopic mites, and Helicobacter pylori bacteria.
Treatment for rosacea involves self-help measures, such as avoiding triggers, as well as medications like creams, oral antibiotics, and laser or intense pulsed light (IPL) treatment.
Scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by tiny mites that burrow into the skin.
The main symptom of scabies is intense itching that's worse at night. It also causes a skin rash on areas where the mites have burrowed.
Scabies mites are called Sarcoptes scabiei. They feed using their mouths and front legs to burrow into the outer layer of skin (epidermis), where they lay eggs.
Scabies is usually spread through prolonged periods of skin-to-skin contact with an infected person, or through sexual contact.
Scarlet fever is a bacterial illness that mainly affects children and causes a distinctive pink-red rash.
The illness is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes bacteria, also known as Group A Streptococcus, which are found on the skin and in the throat.
Symptoms of scarlet fever include a sore throat, headache, swollen neck glands, loss of appetite, nausea or vomiting, red lines in the folds of the body, and a white coating on the tongue.
Scarlet fever is highly contagious and can be spread through airborne droplets, skin contact, and sharing contaminated items.
Schizophrenia is a long-term mental health condition that causes hallucinations, delusions, muddled thoughts, and changes in behavior.
The exact cause of schizophrenia is unknown, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Schizophrenia is most often diagnosed between the ages of 15 and 35 and affects men and women equally.
Treatment for schizophrenia usually involves a combination of medication, such as antipsychotics, and therapy, such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT).
Scoliosis is the abnormal twisting and curvature of the spine.

Typical signs of scoliosis include a visibly curved spine, one shoulder being higher than the other, one shoulder or hip being more prominent than the other, clothes not hanging properly, a prominent ribcage, and a difference in leg lengths.
Scoliosis can be caused by conditions such as cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, Marfan syndrome, and neurofibromatosis.
Treatment for scoliosis in children may include observation, casting, bracing, or surgery, depending on the severity and age of the child.
Septic shock is a life-threatening condition that occurs when blood pressure drops to a dangerously low level after an infection.
People with a weakened immune system, such as newborn babies, elderly individuals, and those with long-term health conditions, are at a higher risk of developing septic shock.
Treatment for septic shock may involve oxygen therapy, intravenous fluids, medication to increase blood flow, antibiotics, and in some cases, surgery.
Complications of septic shock can include respiratory failure, heart failure, kidney failure or injury, and abnormal blood clotting.
The main symptom of shingles is pain, followed by a rash that develops into itchy blisters.
Other symptoms of shingles may include a headache, burning, tingling, numbness or itchiness of the skin in the affected area, a feeling of being generally unwell, and a high temperature (fever).
The shingles rash usually appears on one side of the body and can develop new blisters for up to a week before drying out and forming scabs.
Treatment for shingles involves keeping the rash clean and dry, wearing loose-fitting clothing, using a cool damp cloth to soothe the skin, and taking painkillers or antiviral tablets as prescribed.
Sudden shortness of breath is the most common reason for visiting a hospital accident and emergency department.
Long-term shortness of breath is usually caused by obesity, poorly controlled asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), anaemia, heart failure, or a problem with heart rate or rhythm.
Sudden breathlessness could be caused by asthma, pneumonia, or a worsening of COPD.
Shortness of breath may be a warning sign of a heart attack, heart failure, or a problem with heart rate or rhythm.
Sickle cell disease is a group of blood disorders that are inherited and affect how the body produces red blood cells.
The main symptoms of sickle cell disease include sickle cell crises, infections, and anaemia.
People with sickle cell disease are more vulnerable to infections and may need to take daily doses of antibiotics.
Treatment for sickle cell disease includes managing and preventing sickle cell crises, treating and preventing infections, and managing anaemia and other related symptoms.
Sinusitis is inflammation of the sinuses, which are small, air-filled spaces in the cheekbones and forehead.
Symptoms of sinusitis include a green or yellow discharge from the nose, a blocked nose, pain and tenderness around the cheeks, eyes, or forehead, and a high temperature.
Sinusitis is usually caused by a viral infection and typically improves within 2 to 3 weeks.
Treatment for sinusitis includes rest, drinking fluids, taking over-the-counter painkillers, using nasal decongestants, and cleaning the nose with a salt water solution.
Sj'gren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that affects the tear and saliva glands, causing dry eyes and dry mouth.
It is classified as either primary, when it develops by itself, or secondary, when it occurs in combination with another autoimmune disorder.
Diagnosis can be difficult due to the similarity of symptoms to other conditions, but tests such as tear break-up time and blood tests can help confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms and may include artificial tears, saliva substitutes, and medication such as pilocarpine or hydroxychloroquine.
Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that can spread to other organs in the body.
The most common sign of melanoma is the appearance of a new mole or a change in an existing mole.
Melanoma can appear anywhere on the body, but the back, legs, arms, and face are most commonly affected.
Melanoma is caused by exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light from natural or artificial sources.
Non-melanoma skin cancer refers to a group of cancers that slowly develop in the upper layers of the skin.
The first sign of non-melanoma skin cancer is usually the appearance of a lump or patch on the skin that doesn't heal after a few weeks.
The two most common types of non-melanoma skin cancer are basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma.
Non-melanoma skin cancer is mainly caused by overexposure to ultraviolet (UV) light, such as sunlight and artificial sunbeds.

Phone 999 or go to A&E if a child has a rash and has a stiff neck, is bothered by light, seems confused, has a high temperature, has difficulty breathing, has a rash that looks like small bruises or bleeding under the skin and does not fade when pressed, or their skin, lips, or tongue look pale, blue, grey, or blotchy.

Cellulitis is an infection of the deeper layers of skin and underlying tissue. Symptoms include red, painful, swollen, and hot skin, often affecting the legs, and a fever. It can be diagnosed by assessing symptoms and usually responds well to treatment with antibiotics.

Chickenpox is a viral illness that causes an itchy, spotty rash that can be anywhere on the body. The spots turn into fluid-filled blisters that crust over and eventually drop off. Treatment involves managing symptoms with remedies like paracetamol and calamine lotion.

Eczema is a long-term condition that causes itchy, red, dry, and cracked skin, often developing on the backs of the knees, elbows, neck, eyes, and ears. It can flare up into an outbreak of tiny blisters if infected with the herpes simplex virus. Treatment involves using creams and ointments to
Slapped cheek syndrome, also known as fifth disease or parvovirus B19, is a viral infection that causes a bright red rash on the cheeks.
