Most cases of slapped cheek syndrome are mild and clear up on their own within 1 to 3 weeks, with lifelong immunity after infection.
Pregnant women, individuals with blood disorders or weakened immune systems, and those exposed to the virus should seek medical advice.
Symptoms of slapped cheek syndrome include a slight fever, runny nose, sore throat, headache, upset stomach, and feeling unwell. A distinctive rash on the cheeks may also appear.
Soft tissue sarcomas are rare cancers that affect the tissues connecting, supporting, and surrounding other body structures and organs.
They can develop in various tissues such as fat, muscle, blood vessels, deep skin tissues, tendons, and ligaments.
Soft tissue sarcomas can occur in different parts of the body, including the legs, arms, and trunk.
There are different types of soft tissue sarcomas, such as leiomyosarcomas, liposarcomas, angiosarcomas, and gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs).
Soft tissue sarcomas are cancers that develop from cells in the soft, supporting tissues of the body, such as muscle, cartilage, fat, fibrous tissue, nerves, and blood vessels.

The symptoms of soft tissue sarcomas depend on where the cancer is located, but may include a painless lump or swelling in the limb, a painful and swollen tummy, difficulty urinating, breathlessness and chest pain, and a lump or blockage in the head or neck.
The causes of soft tissue sarcomas in teenagers and young adults are unknown, and there is no evidence to suggest that a knock or injury can cause the cancer.
The main treatments for soft tissue sarcomas are surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. The specific treatment plan depends on the type, stage, and grade of the cancer.
Sore throats are very common and usually get better within a week.
Treatments for a sore throat include taking ibuprofen or paracetamol, drinking plenty of fluids, eating cool, soft foods, and gargling with warm, salty water.
Antibiotics are not usually prescribed for a sore throat, as they are unlikely to make you feel better any quicker and have unpleasant side effects.
Causes of a sore throat can include viral or bacterial infections, colds or flu, laryngitis, tonsillitis, strep throat, glandular fever, and irritants such as smoke or acid reflux.
Some people are born without a spleen or need to have it removed because of disease or injury.
The spleen is a fist-sized organ found in the upper left side of your abdomen, next to your stomach and behind your left ribs.
The spleen fights invading germs in the blood, controls the level of blood cells, and screens the blood and removes old or damaged red blood cells.
Spleen problems can include spleen pain, a damaged or ruptured spleen, and an enlarged spleen.
A stillbirth is when a baby dies after the 24th week of a pregnancy or during birth.
The causes of stillbirth can vary and may be linked to problems with the placenta, the mother's health, or the baby's health and development.
After a stillbirth, it is important to seek support from healthcare professionals and to consider registering the stillbirth and making funeral arrangements.
Recovering from a stillbirth involves physical and emotional care, and many parents find comfort in finding ways to remember their baby.
A stomach ache is cramps or a dull ache in the tummy (abdomen).
Stomach cramps with bloating are often caused by trapped wind.
If your stomach cramps have started recently and you also have diarrhoea, the cause may be a tummy bug (gastroenteritis).
Sudden agonising pain in a particular area of your abdomen may be a sign of a serious problem.
Stomach cancer, or gastric cancer, is a fairly uncommon type of cancer.
The initial symptoms of stomach cancer include persistent indigestion and heartburn, trapped wind and frequent burping, feeling very full or bloated after meals, and persistent stomach pain.
Symptoms of advanced stomach cancer can include blood in stools, loss of appetite, and weight loss.
Stomach cancer is usually easier to treat if it's diagnosed early, so it's important to get any possible symptoms checked by a doctor as soon as possible.
Stomach ulcers, also known as gastric ulcers, are open sores that develop on the lining of the stomach or the intestine.
The main symptom of a stomach ulcer is a burning or gnawing pain in the center of the abdomen, but not all ulcers are painful.
Stomach ulcers can be caused by an infection with Helicobacter pylori bacteria or by taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen or aspirin.

Treatment for stomach ulcers may involve antibiotics to treat an H. pylori infection, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) to reduce stomach acid, and lifestyle changes such as avoiding stress and spicy foods.
Group A Streptococcus (GAS), also known as Strep A, can cause mild sore throat (strep throat) and skin/soft tissue infections such as impetigo and cellulitis.
GAS infections can also lead to more serious conditions such as tonsillitis, scarlet fever, pneumonia, and post-streptococcal complications like rheumatic fever and glomerulonephritis.
Invasive group A Streptococcus (iGAS) infections, although rare, can cause severe conditions like septic arthritis, meningitis, necrotizing fasciitis, and Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.
Most GAS infections do not require antibiotics and can clear up on their own, but antibiotics may be prescribed in certain cases or for individuals at risk of complications.
Sunburn is skin damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) rays and usually causes red, sore, and tender skin for about a week.
It's important to avoid sunburn because it can increase the risk of developing serious health problems, such as skin cancer, later in life.
To relieve sunburn symptoms, cool the skin with cold water or compresses, drink plenty of fluids, take pain relief medication, and avoid sunlight until the skin has fully healed.
Seek medical advice if sunburn is severe, covers a large area, or if there are symptoms like blistering, swelling, high temperature, dizziness, or if a young child or baby has sunburn.
Supraventricular tachycardia is a condition where the heartbeat is abnormally fast.
It can happen to anyone at any age and often occurs for the first time in children or young adults.
Symptoms of supraventricular tachycardia include feeling the heart racing in the chest or throat, chest pain, dizziness, light-headedness, fatigue, and breathlessness.
Common causes of supraventricular tachycardia include stress, anxiety, a change in posture, certain medications, alcohol, caffeine, smoking, and recreational drugs.
Swollen lymph glands are usually a sign of infection and typically improve on their own within 1 to 2 weeks.
If swollen lymph glands are accompanied by difficulty swallowing or breathing, it is important to seek urgent medical attention.

Contact your GP if swollen lymph glands are getting larger, persist for more than 1 week, feel hard or immobile, are accompanied by night sweats or a high temperature, or are located above or below the collarbone.
Swollen lymph glands are commonly caused by viral or bacterial infections such as colds, tonsillitis, glandular fever, throat or ear infections, dental abscesses, or cellulitis.
Most people with syphilis don't notice any symptoms and don't know they have it. Symptoms change over time and may come and go.
The first stage of syphilis, known as primary syphilis, is characterized by the presence of a small, painless sore or ulcer on the genitals, anus, rectum, tongue, lips, or other areas.
The second stage of syphilis, known as secondary syphilis, is characterized by symptoms such as a non-itchy skin rash, tiredness, headaches, and swollen lymph glands.
If left untreated, syphilis can progress to the third stage, known as tertiary syphilis, which can cause serious symptoms such as stroke, dementia, paralysis, and heart disease.
Testicular cancer is most common in men between the ages of 15 and 49.
The main symptom of testicular cancer is a painless lump or swelling in one of the testicles.
Other symptoms can include a dull ache or sharp pain in the testicles or scrotum, a feeling of heaviness in the scrotum, and a change in the texture or increase in firmness of a testicle.

Risk factors for testicular cancer include undescended testicles, a family history of the condition, previous testicular cancer, age and race, exposure to endocrine disruptors, infertility, smoking, and HIV/AIDS.
Testicles are small and oval-shaped and hang below the penis in a sac called the scrotum.
Testicles produce testosterone, which is responsible for lower voice, hair growth, muscle development, sex drive, and erections.
Testicles produce sperm from puberty onwards, which can cause pregnancy when it meets with a female egg during sex.
Testicular cancer can spread to lymph nodes in the abdomen, and surveillance and further surgery may be required for treatment.
Testicular lumps and swellings can occur in boys, men, and anyone with testicles.
It is important to be aware of what is normal for your testicles in order to notice any changes.
Medical advice should be sought if there is a lump, swelling, change in shape or feel, asymmetry, or persistent discomfort in the testicles.
Causes of testicular lumps and swellings include varicoceles, hydroceles, epididymal cysts, epididymo-orchitis, inguinal hernias, testicular torsion, and testicular cancer.
Excessive and persistent thirst (known as polydipsia) could be a sign of an underlying problem such as diabetes.
Thirst may be caused by dehydration, which can occur due to sweating heavily, vomiting, or diarrhea.
Feeling thirsty all the time, along with other symptoms such as frequent urination and unexplained weight loss, could be a sign of diabetes.
Thirst and increased urination are common symptoms in pregnancy, but can also be a sign of gestational diabetes.
Threadworms, also known as pinworms, are tiny parasitic worms that infect the large intestine of humans.
Threadworms are a common type of worm infection in the UK, particularly in children under the age of 10.
The main symptom of threadworms is intense itching around the anus or vagina, especially at night.
Treatment for threadworms usually involves taking a single dose of medication called mebendazole to kill the worms.
Thrush is a common yeast infection that is not a sexually transmitted infection (STI).
Symptoms of thrush in women include white vaginal discharge, itching and irritation around the vagina, and soreness and stinging during sex or urination.
Symptoms of thrush in men include irritation, burning, and redness around the penis, a white discharge, an unpleasant smell, and difficulty pulling back the foreskin.
Thrush can affect other areas of the body, such as the armpits, groin, and between the fingers, causing a red, itchy, or painful rash and white or yellow discharge.
Thyroid cancer is a rare type of cancer that affects the thyroid gland, a small gland at the base of the neck.
The main symptom of thyroid cancer is a painless lump or swelling in the neck.
Other symptoms may include unexplained hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, and pain in the neck.
Risk factors for thyroid cancer include having a thyroid condition, a family history of thyroid cancer, and exposure to radiation.
The main symptom of thyroid cancer is a painless lump or swelling in the front of the neck that gradually gets bigger.
Other symptoms of thyroid cancer may include a hoarse voice that doesn't get better and difficulty swallowing or breathing.

The causes of thyroid cancer are unknown, but some risk factors include rare genetic conditions, exposure to radiation or radiotherapy treatment to the neck area, and a family history of thyroid cancer.
The main treatment for thyroid cancer is surgery to remove the thyroid gland, and additional treatments may include radioactive iodine and external beam radiotherapy.
Tinnitus is the name for hearing sounds that come from inside your body rather than an outside source.

Symptoms of tinnitus include buzzing, humming, grinding, hissing, whistling, music or singing, and noises that beat in time with your pulse. It may also cause hearing loss and sensitivity to everyday sounds.

It is recommended to speak to your GP if you continually or regularly hear sounds such as buzzing, ringing, or humming in your ears, if your tinnitus is getting worse, if it is bothering you and affecting your daily life, or if you have tinnitus that beats in time with your pulse.

Treatment for tinnitus may involve sound therapy, counseling, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), or tinnitus retraining therapy (TRT). Additionally, relaxation techniques, improving sleep, avoiding stress and loud noises, and joining a support group may help manage symptoms.
Tonsillitis is an infection that causes inflammation of the tonsils.

Symptoms of tonsillitis include a sore throat, pain when swallowing, earache, high temperature, coughing, headache, feeling sick, feeling tired, swollen lymph glands, white pus-filled spots on the tonsils, bad breath, and loss of voice or changes to your voice.
If symptoms last longer than 4 days and don't show signs of improvement, or if symptoms are severe, medical advice should be sought.
Most cases of tonsillitis are caused by a viral infection, but some can be caused by a bacterial infection.
Tooth decay occurs when acid is produced from plaque, which builds up on the teeth.
Symptoms of tooth decay may include toothache, tooth sensitivity, spots on the teeth, bad breath, and an unpleasant taste in the mouth.
Treatment for tooth decay depends on the severity and may involve applying fluoride, filling or crowning the tooth, root canal treatment, or tooth extraction.

Preventing tooth decay involves regular dental visits, reducing sugary and starchy foods, practicing good oral hygiene, avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol consumption, and seeking medical attention for dry mouth.
Toothache is pain in and around the teeth and jaws caused by tooth decay.
Toothache can vary in intensity and may be triggered by hot or cold food and drinks.
Toothache can sometimes be felt in the ear or sinuses, depending on the affected tooth.
Toothache can be caused by tooth decay, cracked teeth, loose or broken fillings, receding gums, or bacterial infections.
A transient ischaemic attack (TIA), or mini stroke, is a temporary disruption in the blood supply to part of the brain.
Symptoms of a TIA can include sudden weakness or numbness on one side of the body, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, and blurred vision.
TIAs are usually caused by a blood clot that blocks the blood vessels supplying the brain, but can also be caused by atrial fibrillation.
Treatment for a TIA may involve taking medication to reduce the risk of a stroke, making lifestyle changes, and in some cases, undergoing surgery to remove blockages in the carotid artery.
Trigeminal neuralgia is a sudden, severe facial pain, described as sharp, shooting or like an electric shock.
The pain usually occurs in sudden short attacks lasting from a few seconds to about two minutes, and it often affects part or all of one side of the face.
Trigeminal neuralgia can be triggered by activities such as washing, eating, or brushing the teeth, but it can also occur without any trigger.
Living with trigeminal neuralgia can be difficult and can have a significant impact on a person's quality of life, resulting in problems such as weight loss, isolation, and depression.
Tuberculosis (TB) is a bacterial infection spread through inhaling tiny droplets from the coughs or sneezes of an infected person.
Typical symptoms of TB include a persistent cough that lasts more than three weeks, weight loss, night sweats, and a high temperature (fever).
TB mainly affects the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body, such as the glands, bones, and nervous system.
Treatment for TB usually involves a long course of antibiotics lasting several months, and most people will need a hospital admission during treatment.
Type 1 diabetes is a lifelong condition that causes high blood glucose levels due to a lack of insulin production by the pancreas.
Symptoms of type 1 diabetes include feeling very thirsty, passing urine more frequently, feeling very tired, weight loss, and persistent infections.
Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune condition where the immune system attacks and destroys the cells in the pancreas that produce insulin.
Treatment for type 1 diabetes involves regular insulin injections, monitoring blood glucose levels, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle.
Type 2 diabetes is a lifelong condition that causes high blood glucose levels.
The main symptoms of type 2 diabetes include increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and blurred vision.
Type 2 diabetes is caused by the body's inability to produce enough insulin or the body's cells not responding properly to insulin.
Treatment for type 2 diabetes may involve lifestyle changes, oral medications, and insulin injections.
Trichomonas is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by a small parasite.
Symptoms of trichomonas may include a yellow or green discharge from the vagina or penis, genital itching and soreness, and pain or a burning sensation when peeing.
Testing for trichomonas can be done by collecting a swab or urine sample, which is then examined under a microscope or sent to a lab for diagnosis.
Trichomonas infection is treated with antibiotics, and both the infected individual and their partner(s) should be treated to prevent reinfection.
Transverse myelitis is a rare neurological condition caused by inflammation of the spinal cord, resulting in damage to the nerves and potential permanent scars or lesions.
Symptoms of transverse myelitis can include muscle weakness in the legs and arms, mobility problems, unusual sensations and numbness, bladder and bowel problems, sexual problems, and pain.
Transverse myelitis can be caused by autoimmune diseases, viral or bacterial infections, or certain cancers.

Treatment for transverse myelitis may involve physiotherapy for muscle weakness, mobility aids, medication for inflammation, management of bladder and bowel problems, and addressing sexual and musculoskeletal pain issues.

Ulcerative colitis is a long-term condition that causes swelling and inflammation in the large bowel (colon and rectum), leading to symptoms such as recurring diarrhea, abdominal pain, and frequent need to pass stools.

In addition to bowel-related symptoms, ulcerative colitis can also cause fatigue, loss of appetite, weight loss, and symptoms in other parts of the body, such as joint pain, mouth ulcers, and skin inflammation.
The exact cause of ulcerative colitis is unknown, but it is believed to involve problems with the immune system, genetic factors, and environmental factors such as air pollution and gut infections.

Treatment for ulcerative colitis may involve medication to control inflammation, including aminosalicylates and corticosteroids, and in severe cases, surgery to remove part or all of the large bowel may be necessary.
An underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) is where your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough hormones.
Common signs of an underactive thyroid are tiredness, weight gain and feeling depressed.
An underactive thyroid can often be successfully treated by taking daily hormone tablets to replace the hormones your thyroid isn't making.

Most cases of an underactive thyroid are caused by the immune system attacking the thyroid gland and damaging it, or by damage that occurs as a result of treatments for thyroid cancer or an overactive thyroid.
Symptoms of an underactive thyroid are often similar to those of other conditions, and they usually develop slowly, so you may not notice them for years.

You should see your GP and ask to be tested for an underactive thyroid if you have symptoms including tiredness, weight gain, depression, being sensitive to the cold, dry skin and hair, and muscle aches.
The only accurate way of finding out whether you have a thyroid problem is to have a thyroid function test, where a sample of blood is tested to measure your hormone levels.
Both men and women can have an underactive thyroid, although it's more common in women. In the UK, it affects 15 in every 1,000 women and 1
Urinary incontinence is when you pee by accident, often during activities like exercise or jumping on a trampoline.
Urinary incontinence can affect anyone, but it is more common in women.
There are ways to prevent urinary incontinence, such as strengthening pelvic floor muscles, staying active, maintaining a healthy weight, and avoiding alcohol and caffeinated drinks.
The most common types of urinary incontinence are stress incontinence (leaking urine when the bladder is under pressure) and urge incontinence (sudden and intense need to pee).
Lower UTIs, also known as cystitis or urethra infections, can cause symptoms such as frequent urination, pain or discomfort when urinating, sudden urges to urinate, and cloudy or foul-smelling urine.
Upper UTIs, which affect the kidneys or ureters, can cause the same symptoms as lower UTIs along with additional symptoms such as high fever, pain in the sides or back, and feeling sick or confused.

It is important to seek urgent medical attention if you experience symptoms such as a very high temperature, confusion, severe pain in the lower abdomen or back, or blood in the urine, as these could indicate a kidney infection.

UTIs are typically treated with a short course of antibiotics, and over-the-counter pain relief and increased fluid intake can help alleviate symptoms. It is important to complete the full course of antibiotics prescribed.
Urinary tract infections (UTIs) can affect the bladder, urethra, and kidneys.
Symptoms of UTIs in children may include vomiting, tiredness, irritability, pain or burning sensation when peeing, frequent urination, and cloudy or unpleasant-smelling pee.
Urgent medical attention is needed if a child under 3 years old has a UTI with a high temperature, confusion, blood in their pee, or pain in the lower tummy or back.
UTIs in children can be treated with antibiotics, and other treatments such as liquid paracetamol may be used to ease symptoms.
The main symptom of hives (urticaria) is a raised and itchy rash.
The rash can be localized to one part of the body or spread over large areas.
The size of the rash can range from a few millimeters to the size of a hand.
The appearance of the rash can change within 24 hours.
Vaginal cancer is a rare type of cancer that begins in the vagina.
The most common symptom of vaginal cancer is abnormal vaginal bleeding, such as bleeding between periods or after sex.
Risk factors for developing vaginal cancer include being infected with certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV), age (over 60), and a history of abnormal cells in the cervix or vagina.
Treatment for vaginal cancer may include radiotherapy, surgery, and chemotherapy, depending on the stage and location of the cancer.
Normal vaginal discharge is odourless, clear or white, thick and sticky, or slippery and wet.
Heavier or more frequent discharge may occur during pregnancy, sexual activity, or while using contraception.

Contact your GP or sexual health service if you experience pelvic pain, bleeding between periods or after sex, pain when peeing, changes in colour, smell or texture of discharge, or itchiness, sores, or blisters.
Vaginal discharge can be caused by STIs such as chlamydia, gonorrhoea, genital herpes, or trichomonas, as well as by thrush or bacterial vaginosis.
Varicose eczema is a long-term skin condition that affects the lower legs and is common in people with varicose veins.
Symptoms of varicose eczema include itching, redness, swelling, dryness, flakiness, and the presence of varicose veins.
Varicose eczema is caused by increased pressure in the leg veins, which leads to fluid leakage and an immune system reaction.
Treatment for varicose eczema involves self-help measures, emollients, topical corticosteroids, and compression stockings.
A venous leg ulcer is a long-lasting sore that develops on the inside of the leg, just above the ankle.
Symptoms of a venous leg ulcer include pain, itching, swelling, discolored or hardened skin, and foul-smelling discharge.
Venous leg ulcers can be caused by persistently high pressure in the leg veins, often due to minor injuries.
Treatment for venous leg ulcers involves cleaning and dressing the wound, using compression bandages or stockings, and addressing underlying causes such as obesity or varicose veins.
Vertigo is the feeling that you or the environment around you is moving or spinning.
Symptoms of vertigo may include loss of balance, feeling sick or being sick, and dizziness.
Inner ear problems and problems in certain parts of the brain are common causes of vertigo.
Treatment for vertigo may involve medications, referral to specialists, and self-help measures such as lying still in a quiet room and avoiding certain head movements.
Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia occurs when a lack of vitamin B12 or folate causes the body to produce abnormally large red blood cells that can't function properly.

Symptoms of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency may include extreme tiredness, a lack of energy, pins and needles, a sore and red tongue, mouth ulcers, muscle weakness, disturbed vision, psychological problems, and problems with memory and judgement.
Causes of vitamin B12 deficiency anaemia include pernicious anaemia, a lack of these vitamins in the diet, certain medications, and conditions affecting the stomach or intestines.
Treatment for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia may involve injections or tablets to replace the missing vitamins, and improving the diet to include foods rich in vitamin B12 or folate.
Nausea and vomiting in adults can be caused by gastroenteritis, which is an infection of the gut usually caused by bacteria or a virus.
Pregnant women often experience nausea and vomiting, known as morning sickness, especially during the early stages of pregnancy.
Recurrent episodes of vomiting along with intense headaches may indicate migraines.
Vomiting accompanied by dizziness or vertigo may be a sign of labyrinthitis, an inner ear infection.
Vulval cancer is a rare type of cancer that affects women and anyone with a vulva.

Symptoms of vulval cancer can include persistent itchiness, pain or tenderness in the vulva, raised and thickened patches of skin, a lump or wart-like growth on the vulva, bleeding or blood-stained discharge, an open sore, burning pain when passing urine, and changes in the shape or color of a mole on the vulva.

Risk factors for vulval cancer include increasing age, vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), persistent infection with certain types of human papilloma virus (HPV), skin conditions affecting the vulva, and smoking.
Treatment for vulval cancer may involve surgery to remove the cancerous tissue and lymph nodes, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of these treatments.
Warts are small lumps that often develop on the skin of the hands and feet, varying in appearance and may develop singly or in clusters.
Warts are caused by certain strains of the human papilloma virus (HPV) and can be spread through close skin-to-skin contact or contact with contaminated objects.
There are several different types of warts, including common warts, filiform warts, mosaic warts, periungual warts, plane warts, and verrucas.
Treatment options for warts include salicylic acid, cryotherapy, and chemical treatments, while surgery is not usually recommended.
Whooping cough, also known as pertussis, is a highly contagious bacterial infection of the lungs and airways.
Symptoms of whooping cough include a runny nose, red and watery eyes, sore throat, raised temperature, intense coughing bouts, vomiting, gasping for breath, and a "whoop" sound during breathing.
Whooping cough can affect people of any age, but babies under 6 months are at an increased risk of complications.
Treatment for whooping cough may include hospitalization for severe cases, antibiotics to reduce the spread of infection, rest, fluids, and pain relief medication.
Wilms' tumour is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children under the age of 5.
The causes of Wilms' tumour are largely unknown, but in rare cases, it may be associated with certain congenital malformations or a family history of the condition.

The most common symptom of Wilms' tumour is a painless swelling in the abdomen, although other symptoms may include blood in the urine, high blood pressure, fever, upset stomach, weight loss, and loss of appetite.

Treatment for Wilms' tumour typically involves surgery to remove the affected kidney, followed by chemotherapy and, in some cases, radiotherapy. Regular check-ups are necessary to monitor for recurrence or long-term complications.
Abnormal vaginal bleeding is the most common symptom of womb cancer, including bleeding between periods and after menopause.
Womb cancer is more common in women aged 40 to 74, particularly those who have not had children and those who are overweight or obese.
Treatment for womb cancer may involve a hysterectomy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or hormone therapy, depending on the stage and grade of the cancer.

After treatment, regular check-ups will be necessary to monitor the cancer and manage any side effects. Support is available for emotional and physical challenges, including changes in relationships and sex life.
Yellow fever is a serious viral infection spread by certain types of mosquitoes, mainly found in sub-Saharan Africa, South America, and parts of the Caribbean.
The infection can be prevented with a vaccination and is rare among travellers, with only 12 cases reported among European travellers between 1999 and 2018.
Symptoms of yellow fever include fever, headache, nausea or vomiting, muscle pain, and loss of appetite. In severe cases, jaundice, kidney failure, and bleeding may occur.
There is no specific treatment for yellow fever, but symptoms can be managed and supportive care is provided in a hospital setting.
